title: How to dress better for the planet â€“ and your budget
excerpt: Last year, in the interest of sustainable fashion, I joined a pledge only to buy five new pieces of clothing . Despite thinking of myself as someone who doesnâ€™t really shop, I found the restriction a real chore. Unless youâ€™re buying vintage or spending a fortune, the dilemma oâ€¦
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Last year, in the interest of sustainable fashion, I joined a pledge only to buy five new pieces of clothing. Despite thinking of myself as someone who doesnâ€™t really shop, I found the restriction a real chore. Unless youâ€™re buying vintage or spending a fortune, the dilemma of how to engage in the fun and newness of fashion without contributing to its environmental footprint is, it turns out, nearly universal: data in a new report reveals 74% of people want to dress more sustainably but most donâ€™t know how to go about it.

The Guardianâ€™s journalism is independent. We will earn a commission if you buy something through an affiliate link.Â Learn more.

The report â€“ released by multi-brand retailer Zalando and GlobeScan â€“ found that 41% of consumers find sustainable garments too expensive and 27% say they are hard to identify. Itâ€™s little wonder sustainable fashion remains plagued by vague claims, convoluted supply chains and a call-out culture thatâ€™s left brands reluctant to promote initiatives to customers on the lookout for greenwashing.

â€œPeople are more engaged than theyâ€™re often given credit for,â€ says Pascal Brun, Zalandoâ€™s vice-president of sustainability and D&I. Almost two decades after sustainable fashion entered mainstream discourse, most people have some awareness of the industryâ€™s environmental impact â€“ carbon emissions, pollution of waterways, deforestation, microplastics, waste. They probably also know these ill effects are exacerbated by the sheer volume of product being made every year (somewhere between 80 and 150bn garments) and the increasing proportion derived from fossil-fuel based fabrics (polyester accounted for 57% of all fibres in 2024).

The rising popularity of ultra-cheap, ultra-fast fashion brands such as Shein and Temu (the targets of French legislation passed last week) brings the dilemma into stark focus. Yet this new data reveals, despite everyoneâ€™s best intentions, itâ€™s not clear where and how to shop with a reduced impact. So, how does one buy reasonably priced, sustainable clothes?

The starting point is, of course, vintage â€“ sales of which happily, according to ThredUpâ€™s Annual Resale Report, grew by 15% in 2024. Data from eBay suggests users search for â€œvintageâ€ items more than 1,200 times a minute. But given the constraints on sizing and the time required to sift through racks, second-hand clothing isnâ€™t always practical.

When buying new clothes, context is important, says author and fashion educator Andrea Cheong. â€œWhat is financially accessible to people is going to vary, as is what is sustainable.â€ So rather than focusing on brands, she suggests buying the best quality of the item your budget can accommodate. That way, you will actually wear it. To assess quality, apply three criteria. First, buy nothing that contains a synthetic or semi-synthetic blend. Second, the garment must look as good on the inside as it does on the outside (small stitches, neat seams, non-synthetic lining). And third, it must be fit for purpose (leggings that are supportive enough for a workout, coats that keep you warm, pockets deep and sturdy enough to hold your phone).

Detail is your friend. Garments made from a single, natural fibre (100% cotton, linen or wool) are easier to recycle and generally more durable. If a brand is using sustainable materials, they will tell you about it â€“ and provide the nitty-gritty; specificity is the enemy of greenwashing. Look for third-party certifications that promote safe use of chemicals including Bluesign and Oeko-Tex, or regenerative or organic farming practices such as the Responsible Wool Standard and the Global Organic Textile Standard (Gots), or the inclusion of recycled content like the Global Recycled Standard.

Similarly, if a brand has engaged suppliers with closed-loop systems (to recycle water and chemicals) and renewable energy, who are paying a living wage, they will include this detail, as well â€“ most notably â€“ as the location of the factory on their website. This is a detail that reveals a level of trust, transparency and confidence. In addition, brands get bonus points for having repair, rental and resale programmes.

title: â€˜Made in Italyâ€™: is the label just another luxury fashion illusion?
excerpt: For years shoppers have been aware of scandals about the origins of cheap clothing sold in high street stores. Garment industry workers who make clothes for leading brands have been beaten for asking for living wages and notes pleading for help have been found hidden in clothiâ€¦
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
For years shoppers have been aware of scandals about the origins of cheap clothing sold in high street stores. Garment industry workers who make clothes for leading brands have been beaten for asking for living wages and notes pleading for help have been found hidden in clothing. There have also been stories about hidden child labour and some workers in UK factories are feared to be trapped in modern slavery.

Now after a series of labour investigations by Milanese prosecutors, the luxury fashion industry is fast coming under similar scrutiny.

Last week, Loro Piana, the 100-year-old Italian brand that sells four-figure cashmere jumpers and whose â€œquiet luxuryâ€ aesthetic had been championed by celebrities including Gwyneth Paltrow and worn by the super-rich characters in the TV show Succession, was placed under a 12-month court administration over alleged worker exploitation.

The ruling arises from an investigation into Italyâ€™s luxury goods supply chain that began in 2023. According to the court, Loro Piana â€“ owned by the luxury conglomerate LVMH â€“ outsourced production of some clothing including cashmere jackets to an external Chinese-operated fashion company, which in turn subcontracted the work to two other companies. These were illegal workshops that operated on the outskirts of Milan. In May, the labour crime unit of the Carabinieri military police found that 10 Chinese people, five of whom were undocumented migrants, were forced to work up to 90 hours a week for as little as â‚¬4 per hour, as reported by Reuters.

It is worth noting that the brand is not under criminal investigation and if the company complies with a set of legal requirements before the deadline issued by the court, the order will be lifted.

In a statement to the Guardian, Loro Piana said the supplier had not informed the company of the existence of subcontractors. It also said: â€œLoro Piana was made aware of this situation on 20 May, and, as a result, the Maison terminated all relations with the concerned supplier in less than 24 hours.â€

However, news of the order has further tainted the idea of the â€œMade in Italyâ€ label, a term that typically denotes high-quality manufacturing.

Loro Piana is now the fifth fashion house to be placed under court monitoring in Italy since 2023. Armani and LVMHâ€™s Dior have both faced similar action over the last year. In February the monitoring orders placed on them were lifted early as the court said both brands had taken all the necessary corrective action before the 12-month deadline assigned to them had passed. In May a subdivision of Valentino, Valentino Bags Lab Srl, was also placed under judicial administration.

Last year, an investigation by Italian police found that Armani bags that retail for â‚¬1,800 were being made by a Chinese subcontractor for â‚¬93 and then sold on to the group by an intermediary for â‚¬250. A Dior subsidiary was sanctioned for paying as little as â‚¬53 for bags that retail for more than â‚¬2,000, the FT reported.

Loro Piana released a statement about the difference between the price tag on its clothing and the supposed cost to produce it. According to the recent Italian investigation into Loro Piana, some jackets from the brand that can retail for more than â‚¬3,000 were being produced for as little as â‚¬118. The statement said: â€œThe reported cost figures are not representative of the amounts paid by Loro Piana to its supplier, nor do they consider the full value of all the elements, including, among others, raw materials and fabrics.â€

For many consumers, there is a perception that luxury and ethics go hand in hand. But Deborah Lucchetti, who works as a national coordinator at the Italian segment of Clean Clothes Campaign, a network dedicated to improving working conditions and empowering workers in the global garment industry, says that this is an illusion. â€œLuxury is based on a production system founded on cost reduction, profit maximisation and opaque supply chains based on subcontracting, which often employ immigrant workers who have no protection and contracts,â€ she says.

title: â€˜You sold it â€“ now recycle itâ€™: the protesters mailing worn-out clothes to the shops they bought them from
excerpt: In February, a threadbare polycotton bedsheet landed on the desk of Simon Roberts, CEO of Sainsburyâ€™s. A â€œprotest by postâ€, it had been sent by the Sheffield-based designer, maker and eco activist Wendy Ward. â€œI purchased this from Sainsburyâ€™s at least 10 years ago,â€ she wroteâ€¦
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
In February, a threadbare polycotton bedsheet landed on the desk of Simon Roberts, CEO of Sainsburyâ€™s. A â€œprotest by postâ€, it had been sent by the Sheffield-based designer, maker and eco activist Wendy Ward. â€œI purchased this from Sainsburyâ€™s at least 10 years ago,â€ she wrote in the accompanying letter. â€œIt has served me well. However, I have no sustainable options available for what I should do with it.â€ Beyond repair, it was too damaged to donate to a charity shop, she explained. She couldnâ€™t compost it as it had been blended with polyester, and she couldnâ€™t repurpose it as cleaning cloths, as, being polycotton, it wasnâ€™t absorbent. And, she added, â€œI donâ€™t want to put it into a textile recycling collection as the likelihood is that it will be shipped overseas or incinerated and not recycled.â€ Ward qualified her assertions with links to respected sources â€“ as a sustainable fashion PhD student, she is well informed on such matters.

â€œThe only action I can personally take,â€ she continued, â€œis to put it into my general waste bin. I donâ€™t want to do this, as in Sheffield all general waste is incinerated as â€˜energy recoveryâ€™. This isnâ€™t a sustainable option as such processes have been shown to be as damaging to local air pollution as burning coal.â€ So, she concluded, â€œas Sainsburyâ€™s is responsible for designing and manufacturing this product, making decisions to use polycotton with no consideration for what could be done once it reaches the end of its life, I have decided to return it to you. I would really love to hear what you decide to do with it.â€

Sainsburyâ€™s response, sent from its executive office, was â€œa lame fob-offâ€, Ward says, and read as if it had been â€œcut and pasted from a complaints templateâ€. (Sample platitude: â€œSainsburyâ€™s always welcome feedback from customers.â€) But when she shared her protest with her 20,000 Instagram followers, the resounding approval â€“ â€œBrilliant!â€ â€œPlease upload your templateâ€ â€“ motivated her to launch a campaign: #TakeItBack. She created an adaptable, deliberately non-combative letter (â€œIf youâ€™re confrontational, it wonâ€™t go anywhere,â€ she tells me), and encouraged her followers to return their dead clothes to brands. â€œItâ€™s an empowering action,â€ she says. â€œI was wresting back a bit of control as a consumer.â€

I joined Wardâ€™s #TakeItBack campaign, sending my daughterâ€™s ravaged school tights to Marks & Spencerâ€™s CEO, Stuart Machin. To the UK heads of Uniqlo and H&M, I sent my kidsâ€™ damaged polyester-blend T-shirts, and to French Connectionâ€™s CEO, a greyed, misshapen T-shirt of mine thatâ€™s so timeworn, itâ€™s transparent, all accompanied by a version of Wardâ€™s letter. I know theyâ€™ve all been received, because I tracked them, on Wardâ€™s advice; similarly, I washed everything first. M&S was the first to respond, reminding me about its â€œindustry-leading sustainability programmeâ€, Plan A, and its take-back scheme. Uniqlo sent a letter acknowledging mine, and â€œwill respond as soon as possibleâ€. I havenâ€™t heard back from H&M or French Connection yet.

Ward recommends following up if they donâ€™t answer the key questions: â€œWhat would you suggest I do with this item?â€ and â€œWhat are you actually doing about this problem?â€ Sheâ€™s unsure how many people have joined her campaign, though she doesnâ€™t expect vast numbers yet: â€œI know Iâ€™m preaching to the converted.â€

You may be thinking: why not donate your unwanted clothes and other textiles to a charity shop? End-of-life textiles have for many years been a valuable revenue stream for charities. Rag merchants would buy them by weight and sell them on to be down-cycled into stuffing, blankets, wipes etc. But many UK charity shops are now â€œhaving to spend money getting rid of waste textilesâ€, says Dawn Dungate, an independent consultant who advises charities on textile recycling. Indeed, Wardâ€™s protest was inspired by a sign in her local charity shop asking customers to dispose of â€œdamaged, torn or worn-out itemsâ€ in the bin, â€œas the cost of disposal is very highâ€.

title: How the campus became the new catwalk
excerpt: Itâ€™s almost September, which means â€œback to schoolâ€ season is in full swing. But this year itâ€™s not just British schoolgoers being bombarded with uniform reminders and lunchbox ideas. The classroom comeback now extends to university students. Welcome to a new era of the commodâ€¦
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Itâ€™s almost September, which means â€œback to schoolâ€ season is in full swing. But this year itâ€™s not just British schoolgoers being bombarded with uniform reminders and lunchbox ideas. The classroom comeback now extends to university students. Welcome to a new era of the commodification of the campus.

The Guardianâ€™s journalism is independent. We will earn a commission if you buy something through an affiliate link.Â Learn more.

Previously, it was easy to differentiate between UK and US campus culture. US students had frat parties, drank from plastic red cups and slept in shared dorm rooms. Meanwhile, UK freshers had house parties, drank cans on the bus and congregated in communal kitchens. But thanks to social media the lines are becoming more blurred. Algorithms have influenced everyone to dress the same and now this is affecting campus culture. Social media is peppered with US and UK students doing room makeover tours and library fit checks, and the only difference between them is their accents and labels. Now, as the illusion of campus life becomes more powerful than the reality of it, brands are attempting to monetise it.

This month Kim Kardashianâ€™s all-powerful shapewear label Skims pivoted from selling Hannibal Lecter-esque face-sculpting wraps to PJs for students to bed rot in. Its first dedicated â€œCampus Collectionâ€ features â€œdorm-approved and lecture-readyâ€ pieces such as jersey capri pants, cropped hoodies and cotton poplin micro shorts modelled by a group of real students (dubbed the â€œSkims Class of 2025â€). On Asos you can browse a â€œStudent Editâ€ comprising over 2,000 pieces that promise to â€œlook on-point in the lecture, library and beyondâ€ â€“ because nothing says reading week like a sheer maxi skirt.

PrettyLittleThingâ€™s â€œBack to Classâ€ edit includes an advertising campaign shot in a library (a gear shift from their usual poolside settings) complete with models wearing preppy polo tops and rugby shirts. The accessories brand Charles & Keith has teamed up with students from Central Saint Martins, photographing them on the fashion schoolâ€™s campus in their favourite pieces from the brand. Even Shein, the mega fast fashion company that churns out up to 10,000 new pieces a day, is hopping on the trend with a â€œCampus Babeâ€ programme where students can apply to be ambassadors for the online retailer and earn a commission on sales. Presumably by never wearing the same piece twice.

â€œStudents have become a crucial audience because theyâ€™re tastemakers,â€ says Nick Drabicky from January Digital, a marketing agency. According to Drabicky, this particular cohort appeals to brands as â€œtheyâ€™re early adopters, hyper-connected, and influence household and peer spending.â€

The campus-focused trend is a knock-on effect from RushTok (an amalgamation of rush week â€“ which is a bit like freshersâ€™ week â€“ and TikTok) , a corner of social media where applicants for elite Greek sororities in the USA document the process of getting a â€œbidâ€ (i.e. membership). The recruitment phenomenon first went viral on TikTok in August 2021 with PNMs (potential new members) sharing their experiences at the University of Alabama, including game nights and synchronised dances. However, it was outfit of the day videos posted from dorm rooms that really captivated viewers. These 60-second videos featured predominantly thin, white, 18-year-olds with bright blond hair and obvious fake tans name-checking brands such as Steve Madden shoes, Kendra Scott earrings, Golden Goose trainers and The Pants Store â€“ which, it turns out, didnâ€™t just sell pants â€“ in a distinctive southern drawl. Viewers who prior to the videos were blissfully unaware of what a Panhellenic sorority is â€“ and lived in countries such as the UK where they donâ€™t even exist â€“ began to mimic them, while phrases such as â€œMy jewelry is normalâ€ were then commoditised and turned into merch.

Four years later and the yearly event has become akin to a reality TV show, with brands keen to get involved.

There is a very specific panic around summer dressing â€“ all that flesh on show, for starters. So it always seems strange just how little thought we give to it. Obviously you care what you look like, but think how much time and energy you put into finding the perfect winter coat, or boots to see you through the post-Christmas doldrums. Some of you probably save up, or at least try on a few different styles to see what you like. Compare that to choosing a swimsuit or shorts. How often do you buy something the day before you go on holiday, or even at the airport? Youâ€™ll probably spend more time in your coat and boots but still, itâ€™s a bit daft panic-buying some sandals before finding out, mid-hike, that the back strap rubs your heel and they slip off the moment your feet get sweaty.

The truth is that aside from the fact that people equate wearing fewer clothes with being cooler â€“ not true! â€“ itâ€™s very hard to know what to wear when the sun comes out. So we are here to help. How about a tank that needs no bra, a swimsuit that doubles as a top, and a quick-dry, no-towel towel? Or a T-shirt for the guys thatâ€™s cocktail-approved â€“ and a hat the kids will actually wear?

The perfect summer look is a mythical unicorn, but there are things you can invest in now that will see you through until late September and, ideally, multiple summers to come.Morwenna Ferrier

Womenswear by Jess Cartner-Morley

The full-coverage dress your summer wardrobe needs

Counterintuitive though it is, the summer dress I wear most has long sleeves and is almost ankle length. A full-coverage but super-light dress is so much more useful than any number of itsy-bitsy sundresses. It keeps the rays off if itâ€™s hot, the air conditioning off when youâ€™re inside, and doesnâ€™t leave you goosebumpy in the evening. Great for holiday days, office days, travelling days. Look for one you can wear with a bra â€“ this one has a cut-out at the back, but above bra-strap height â€“ and ensure itâ€™s a generous fit.

The cami that works as evening wear

A friend asked me the other day if she could borrow â€œthat lovely Stella McCartney camisoleâ€. Turns out she meant this, which is actually a silk camisole from M&S. So chic for a night out with jeans, blazer and kitten heels.

A clash course

Instead of striped trousers and a plain T-shirt, try clashing your prints. Think stripes and florals. Leopard and polka dots. Camo and gingham. The more unexpected, the better.

A tank top with a built-in bra

If you have huge boobs, this isnâ€™t going to work, so apologies, but for many women, a top with a built-in bra is ideal when you want that sleek, no-bra-strap vest-top look but also a bit of support. I love these Uniqlo ones because the support layer is totally invisible, and the tank isnâ€™t too tight.

The Â£35 M&S swimsuit thatâ€™s a modern classic

Two years ago, I bought a black neoprene scallop-edged bikini from M&S. I love it so much that this year I added the one-piece version. I have it in emerald, which is now sold out, but the tomato red is possibly even nicer, and the white is very Talented Mr Ripley coded.

The not-too-long, not-too-short shorts

Itâ€™s not so much that Iâ€™m too old to wear baggy knee-length shorts â€“ no one is too old to wear anything â€“ itâ€™s more that Iâ€™m old enough to know I donâ€™t have to wear anything that makes me feel ridiculous just because itâ€™s fashionable. Same goes for tiny Daisy Dukes. A short that hits the midâ€‘point of the thigh is the answer. This length can look a bit dowdy in linen, so Iâ€™d go with denim. And possibly a belt for added smarts.

title: Celebrate the rise of accessible design â€“ it benefits everyone
excerpt: Fashion is a vocabulary. Clothing communicates parts of who we are, what we are interested in and how we want to be seen. It reveals choices that we make â€“ but it also exposes lack of choice.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Fashion is a vocabulary. Clothing communicates parts of who we are, what we are interested in and how we want to be seen. It reveals choices that we make â€“ but it also exposes lack of choice.

I am a disabled woman; I have dwarfism. My disability and stature is obvious and often shapes a first interaction. Iâ€™ve learned to love scouring through rails of clothes in high street stores and charity shops, and taking the items for alterations to make sure they fit. I know that if there are patterns or embroidery near the shoulder or ankle of a garment, altering it wonâ€™t work. Iâ€™ve found that jeans and trousers have to be elasticated at the back so they go over my hips with ease and donâ€™t gape at the back. Iâ€™ve also learned that dresses and skirts should have an asymmetrical hemline to accommodate the curve in my spine. As Iâ€™ve got older, Iâ€™ve discovered that many of these alterations donâ€™t just work for me, but would also improve comfort, independence and dressing for most people. Accessible design is better design.

To show you what this looks like in action: I recently had the pleasure of attending a dinner to mark Jannik Sinnerâ€™s return to Wimbledon. Beforehand, I was nervous. I wanted to wear something that would instil confidence, be comfortable and allow me to move about with personality and dignity. I chose a blazer, cashmere jumper and black pants. During my time working in fashion, I had the privilege of building relationships with designers, and this jacket was custom-made by Gucci. The pocket is proportional and the buttons are deliberately placed to be mindful of my figure. The wool pants are also custom-made by Prada and close with a fastener and zip, rather than a button, to avoid dexterity issues, and the back of the waistband is elasticated. The jumper is from Johnstons of Elgin in Scotland â€“ their store is step-free and has rails at multiple levels. I chose it because it needed no alterations; the short-sleeve is midâ€‘length for me, and wearable throughout the year.

Iâ€™ve spent almost a decade working in the luxury fashion industry, because I want more choice, more representation and more respect for disabled customers â€“ and across the industry there is lots to celebrate.

after newsletter promotion

The Victoria and Albert Museum currently has an exhibition called Design and Disability, curated by Natalie Kane, that shows the innovation in accessibility. ItÂ features the work of Victoria Jenkins, the disabled designer behind Unhidden, aÂ leading adaptive brand that will be part of this yearâ€™s official London Fashion Week.

Tommy Hilfiger has an adaptive collection, Liberare creates bras that close at the front rather than the back, Tilt Beauty has a line of products that allow you to put mascara on with greater ease, and Primark has increased representation in the in-store mannequins and begun to make their childrenswear range seam- and label-free for neurodivergent kids. But, we need to think of disabled people as more than customers.

In 2020, I founded Tilting the Lens, aÂ strategic accessibility consultancy that aims to create the conditions for disabled people to be successful. Weâ€™ve developed a scholarship for disabled designers with Parsons School of Design in New York, and weâ€™ve spent the past year undertaking research with more than 200 disabled people across the UK to develop a white paper on adaptive fashion, to improve understanding of the market and innovation opportunities. Weâ€™ve learned so much about making clothingÂ more inclusive, but also the need for stores and real estate, packing and delivery to be accessible, too. IÂ want disabled people to be valued consumers â€“ but for that to happen theyÂ also need to be decision-makers, leaders and trustees.

title: Shein opens investigation after shirt listing displayed image resembling Luigi Mangione
excerpt: The clothing company Shein said it has opened an internal investigation after its website briefly displayed a shirt listing featuring an image resembling Luigi Mangione, the man accused of killing Brian Thompson, the CEO of UnitedHealthcare, in New York last year.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
The clothing company Shein said it has opened an internal investigation after its website briefly displayed a shirt listing featuring an image resembling Luigi Mangione, the man accused of killing Brian Thompson, the CEO of UnitedHealthcare, in New York last year.

The image appeared to show Mangione in a short-sleeved white shirt, and the top was reportedly priced at just under $10.

In a statement shared with various media outlets, the company said: â€œThe image in question was provided by a third-party vendor and was removed immediately upon discovery.â€

Exactly when and for how long the shirt was on sale is unclear, with Shein uploading thousands of products every day, but searches for â€œLuigi Mangione Sheinâ€ on Google spiked on Tuesday and the listing began circulating across social media.

An archived posting of the product description for the â€œMenâ€™s New Spring/Summer Short Sleeve Blue Ditsy Floral White Shirtâ€ shows the item was nearly sold out, with only one size left in stock.

Mangione, 27, was arrested last December and charged in connection with the fatal shooting of Thompson. In April, he pleaded not guilty to all federal counts, including murder and stalking, and awaits trial. Prosecutors have announced they will pursue the death penalty if he is found guilty.

After the killing, some people opposed to the US healthcare system framed Mangione as a folk hero, with some rallying outside the courthouse during his appearances and contributing thousands of dollars to Mangioneâ€™s defense fund. Others have condemned the glorifying of violence and vigilantism.

Some online retailers, including Etsy, saw a wave of merchandise using his name. Amazon said it had removed any such products from its site.

Shein, founded in China, has built its global reputation on inexpensive, fast-moving fashion trends that attract gen Zers and younger millennials. The company has also faced repeated criticism over labor practices, including allegations of forced labor that the company has denied, as well as scrutiny for its environmental footprint.

A spokesperson for Shein said: â€œWe have stringent standards for all listings on our platform. We are conducting a thorough investigation, strengthening our monitoring processes, and will take appropriate action against the vendor in line with our policies.â€

The latest incident comes as the EU justice commissioner, Michael McGrath, vowed to crack down on the sale of goods that break the law. He expressed shock at the dangers of some goods being sold by China-linked online marketplaces such as Shein and its main rival, Temu.

Shein said at the time that it was â€œfully committed to ensuring the products we offer are safe and compliantâ€, while Temu said it had a â€œsystem of seller vetting, proactive monitoring and responsive takedowns to prevent, detect and remove unsafe productsâ€.

Meanwhile, the UK is reviewing rules that allow goods worth less than Â£135 and sent direct to a buyer to enter the UK without paying customs duty. The US recently scrapped its version of the â€œde minimisâ€ rules, which allowed goods worth less than $800 and sent direct to American shoppers to escape customs duty and some checks.

Shein had hoped to list on the London Stock Exchange this year, valued at as much as Â£50bn ($67bn).

However, it is now thought to be pursuing a listing in Hong Kong after failing to win approval from Chinese authorities for a listing in the UK. British MPs and investors have also raised questions about conditions in the groupâ€™s supply chain.

title: Vogue names Chloe Malle as new head of US edition
excerpt: The biggest job in fashion has finally been filled.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
The biggest job in fashion has finally been filled.

Following news that Anna Wintour was stepping back as editor of American Vogue in July, CondÃ© Nast have appointed 39-year-old journalist and Vogue staffer Chloe Malle as head of editorial content at the American fashion magazine. Her role is effective immediately.

â€œFashion and media are both evolving at breakneck speed, and I am so thrilled, and awed, to be part of that,â€ said Malle in a statement. â€œI also feel incredibly fortunate to still have Anna just down the hall as my mentor.â€

One of the most powerful roles in the fashion industry, her appointment marks not just a new chapter for the magazine but for Wintour herself, who will stay on in her role as chief content officer for CondÃ© Nast and global editorial director for the magazine, allowing her to retain control of the magazine, while no longer being involved in the day to day. Wintour was present at the July couture shows and itâ€™s likely that both she and Malle will be present for next weekâ€™s New York fashion week, oversee the Met Gala and Vogue World events. But in a first for the most famous magazine in the world, Vogue no longer has an editor-in-chief.

â€œAt a moment of change both within fashion and outside it, Vogue must continue to be both the standard-bearer and the boundary-pushing leader,â€ said Wintour. â€œChloe has proven often that she can find the balance between American Vogueâ€™s long, singular history and its future on the front lines of the new. I am so excited to continue working with her, as her mentor but also as her student, while she leads us and our audiences where weâ€™ve never been before.â€

Malle was editor of Vogue.com and co-host of the podcast The Run-Through with Vogue, and is a longtime Wintour insider, having been at the magazine since 2011. Responsible for editor-led newsletters, and successful annual â€œwittyâ€ tentpoles such as Dogue (a dog fashion magazine), she is more of a broad stroke journalist than a fashion insider. In 2014, she told Into the Gloss that she was â€œhesitant when I was interviewing, because fashion is not one of my main interests in life, and I wanted to be a writer more than an editor, but I was so seduced by the Vogue machine that I couldnâ€™t resistâ€.

Still, a frontrunner since Wintourâ€™s announcement, Malleâ€™s appointment will come as no surprise to anyone tracking CondÃ© Nastâ€™s revolving door. The former editor-in-chief is known for rewarding close deputies with international roles â€“ Mark Guiducci, Wintourâ€™s Vogueâ€™s creative editorial director, was recently helicoptered into the top job at Vanity Fair.

The gig was arguably up once Malle covered the high stakes and much-discussed Jeff Bezos-Lauren Sanchez wedding in Venice earlier this year. Given access to the bride before the ceremony and tasked with gathering additional details in the run-up to the wedding, the cover story followed her 2023 interview with the couple, and both are seen as proof of her mettle when juggling high profile celebrities with consumer interest.

A graduate of Brown University, Malle grew up in Los Angeles and began her career writing about property for the New York Observer. She has since written for the New York Times, Marie Claire, the Wall Street Journal and Architectural Digest. She joined Vogue in the features department 15 years ago, and has worked across various sections and platforms at the title.

Malle is also the daughter of American actor Candice Bergen, known for her wry humour and icy Nordic characters both on and off the stage, and the late film director Louis Malle, who lived in France because he â€œdidnâ€™t like living or working in Hollywoodâ€, according to a 2015 interview with Bergen in Dallas News. In another curious play between life and art, Bergen had a long-running cameo as the lovelorn editor of US Vogue in Sex and the City. Malle is also one of the few names to have had her birth reported on by People magazine.

title: John Lewis targets gen Z with Topshop revival tie-up
excerpt: John Lewis is to host Topshop in 32 of its 36 stores from February as the clothing brandâ€™s only national stockist on UK high streets, in a drive to attract younger shoppers and their mothers.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
John Lewis is to host Topshop in 32 of its 36 stores from February as the clothing brandâ€™s only national stockist on UK high streets, in a drive to attract younger shoppers and their mothers.

Peter Ruis, the managing director of the staff-owned department store chain, said Topshop â€“ and Topman, which is to go into six outlets â€“ would â€œreally exemplify the new John Lewisâ€, as it tries to broaden its appeal with more fashion, home and beauty brands, ranging from Fenty to the Conran Shop.

He said Topshop was â€œa brand that is going to resonate with our gen Zs [those in their late teens and early 20s] and our gen Xers and everyone in betweenâ€.

Topshop, which launched in Sheffield in 1964, closed all its UK high street stores in 2021 after its parent company, Philip Greenâ€™s Arcadia, went into administration.

The brand was bought out by the online fashion seller Asos, which last week relaunched Topshopâ€™s website and opened an outlet in the London department store Liberty. At its height, Topshop had 300 stores in the UK and 11 in the US.

Ruis said gen X â€“ those in their 40s and 50s â€“ were more interested in fashion than their parents and â€œgrew up with Topshopâ€ and now had the money to buy it, while the younger generations were interested in 90s revival fashion.

â€œI think the best fashion brands are multigenerational. I think thatâ€™s always been the case,â€ he said, suggesting Topshop would â€œbring more of that family day outâ€ to the retailer. Ruis said younger customers were already shopping in its beauty halls alongside their parents and buying brands such as Mango but this would bring a new attraction.

He said Topshop would have a specially created area in stores staffed by handpicked John Lewis staff and was â€œgoing to have a lot of energyâ€.

Michelle Wilson, the managing director of Topshop, said John Lewis had picked a selection of 120 items suitable for its shoppers, including denim, footwear and faux leather jackets, with the most expensive item a Â£250 suede jacket.

She said shoppers â€œabsolutely want to see us back in storesâ€ and wanted to â€œtouch and feel and try on productâ€, with John Lewis being â€œa name trusted by millionsâ€.

Wilson added that Topshop had been â€œpretty open about the fact that we would like our own store presenceâ€ but there was â€œno defined datesâ€ for such a move and the brand was also not looking for other partners on UK high streets.

Ruis said John Lewis, which is due to reveal its half-year results next week, was not abandoning its mainstream customers.

â€œWe are not just a typical luxury fashion and beauty department store. Weâ€™re one that sells you everything in your life,â€ he said, pointing to the chainâ€™s very large market share in sales of cots and gear for babies. He said this broad appeal positioned it well to outlive the difficulties that led to its rivals Debenhams and Beales disappearing from high streets and House of Fraser significantly contracting.

He said John Lewis was â€œsuper positiveâ€ about trading in this yearâ€™s key Christmas period as its customer surveys indicated consumers were â€œmore optimistic than theyâ€™ve been for a very long timeâ€, partly thanks to mortgage rate decreases. â€œWeâ€™re seeing big-ticket items come back with a vengeance,â€ he added, referring to strong sales of sofas and mattresses, in particular.

Last yearâ€™s return of the groupâ€™s now 100-year-old price promise, never knowingly undersold, had gone better than expected, Ruis said, helping to pull in shoppers searching for goods online.

title: â€˜Perfect matchâ€™: Charli xcx in Vivienne Westwood becomes gen Zâ€™s bridal muse
excerpt: Charli xcx is a British pop star known for pioneering trends. Last summer she turned the word â€œBratâ€ into a cultural phenomenon complete with a uniform featuring â€œ a pack of cigs, a Bic lighter, and a strappy white top with no bra .â€
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Charli xcx is a British pop star known for pioneering trends. Last summer she turned the word â€œBratâ€ into a cultural phenomenon complete with a uniform featuring â€œa pack of cigs, a Bic lighter, and a strappy white top with no bra.â€

So it came as somewhat of a surprise to fans when, last weekend, she opted for a more classic bridal look to marry George Daniel, the drummer in the band the 1975.

Arriving at Hackney town hall in east London, the bride wore a white sculpted corseted minidress from Vivienne Westwood. Even her accessories veered towards the traditional: a bouquet of locally grown white cosmos and dahlias, a short white veil, and slingback heels.

Despite the look being more conventional than defiant, Alexandra Macon, the weddings editor of Vogue.com and founder of the e-commerce site Over The Moon, describes the pop starâ€™s choice of designer as a â€œperfect matchâ€.

â€œVivienne Westwood has forged a legacy as a true â€˜anti-brideâ€™ icon in the world of bridal fashion,â€ Macon said.

In 2008, Sex and the Cityâ€™s Carrie Bradshaw was jilted at the altar by Mr Big while wearing a floor-sweeping corseted gown from the British designer. Yet even without the coupleâ€™s eventual happy ending, a Westwood wedding dress has been desired by millennial brides ever since.

Seventeen years later, gen Z have welcomed their own bridal muse. This time the hemline may be shorter but the brand remains the same.

Charli xcxâ€™s dress was inspired by the Cocotte, a style of dress Westwood first unveiled in her autumn/winter 1995 collection. Featuring a swooping neckline, a waist-cinching corset and draping detail on the hip, the original paid homage to the dresses worn by the 17th-century French author and courtesan Ninon de lâ€™Enclos.

Westwood was one of the first to subvert the historical flat corset. Instead of lacing there are zip fastenings, and while the corset still moulds the body there are stretch panels for comfort. Since then, the brand has launched numerous iterations of the silhouette. Off-the-peg versions start from Â£3,200. The style is as popular among celebrities as it is with non-famous brides.

In 2005, Dita Von Teese wore a billowing purple version. Hailey Bieber wore a mini take on it for her nuptials, while Demi Lovato chose a longer length and added a cathedral-style veil. In June, the Hot Milk star Vicky Krieps wore a rose-patterned version for her Greek island wedding, while the model Daisy Lowe customised hers with a bustle and side slit.

Such is its ubiquity that last year Vogue declared it â€œthe wedding dress of the decadeâ€. Macon describes the silhouette as â€œinstantly recognisable and beloved, which is why we see it again and again on bridesâ€.

A finale bridal look has been the brandâ€™s show signature since the 1990s when the model Sara Stockbridge was an unconventional bride, carrying her baby down the catwalk in a dress depicting Jean-HonorÃ© Fragonardâ€™s 1797 painting The Swarm of Cupids.

Bridal is now a core part of the business with a dedicated atelier. In April, Vivienne Westwood staged its first standalone bridal show.

After trying on 120 dresses in her search for her perfect dress, the writer and influencer Katherine Ormerod was surprised to find herself choosing a Cocotte.

â€œNo one wants to be a basic bitch and feel like what theyâ€™re wearing is ubiquitous, but also after all my years working in fashion, Iâ€™ve seen the distinction between something that is trend-led and â€˜everywhereâ€™ and design which is iconic, timeless and popular for a reason,â€ she says.

The Cocotte dress is also a hot ticket item on resale and rental platforms. Ormerod says that â€œin contrast to a sea of algorithmically fine-tuned brands and designsâ€, it â€œfeels like a bit of a FU to the lace and full trainâ€.

Six months after her wedding, Ormerod sold hers. â€œI canâ€™t think of anything sadder than that beautiful dress hanging, Miss Havisham-like, in a dust bag for ever. It wasnâ€™t a hard sell: within a fortnight it had found its new bride.â€

title: â€˜Rage baitâ€™ or good design? The Rowâ€™s Â£600 sliders are an exquisite provocation
excerpt: Rounded, cushioned and with a thick strap, foam sliders have been a familiar sight on feet this summer. While they are available for Â£30 from Adidas or Â£3.49 on the online marketplace Temu, a high-fashion version is now also on offer. The Ama sliders , in a choice of black, reâ€¦
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Rounded, cushioned and with a thick strap, foam sliders have been a familiar sight on feet this summer. While they are available for Â£30 from Adidas or Â£3.49 on the online marketplace Temu, a high-fashion version is now also on offer. The Ama sliders, in a choice of black, red or white, were launched by the American fashion brand The Row this week. They cost Â£600.

Laura Reilly, the writer of the influential fashion newsletter Magasin, called them â€œThe Rowâ€™s latest rage baitâ€, using the name for posts online designed to provoke anger, and go viral in the process.

Fashionâ€™s version of rage bait seems to be luxurious versions of everyday things. It remains unclear whether the creators of these items are deliberately provoking a reaction, but the prices certainly drive some consumers into a fury.

The Ama follows The Rowâ€™s other recent item in this tradition: the Dune sandal, otherwise known as flip-flops with a red sole, which cost Â£670 (they also come with a black sole, as worn by the actor Jonathan Bailey at an event to promote Jurassic World). But the brand is not alone. Items that have prompted similar outrage include a Loewe white vest for Â£325 and the Italian brand Golden Gooseâ€™s â€œdirty trainersâ€, which cost Â£435. Balenciaga, during the decade that Demna has been the creative director, has provided copious items here, from Â£720 Crocs, to a towel â€œskirtâ€ that cost Â£695 and a take on the Ikea Frakta bag for Â£1,365.

Dal Chodha, the pathway leader of Central Saint Martinsâ€™ fashion communication course, is familiar with the genre. â€œThis one in particular is brilliant because itâ€™s so well positioned for us to take offence, in the most exquisite way,â€ he says. â€œThereâ€™s an awful lot of [questions] that come out of looking at that shoe. The first is the one that most people ask themselves when they look at [a] work of art or any piece of luxury fashion: â€˜Why does that cost that much?â€™â€

Taking something ordinary and putting it into a different context has a tradition in the visual arts, one that Balenciagaâ€™s Demna is definitely influenced by. See Marcel Duchampâ€™s urinal in 1917, Jeff Koonsâ€™s 1980 vacuum cleaner and Martin Creedâ€™s light switch from 2000, all items that have prompted public rage.

But if art remains elitist due to the fact that most people canâ€™t buy it, everyone wears clothes, so consumers feel more invested when everyday items are sold for higher prices. This has long created a tension; Daniel Rodgers, the fashion news editor at Vogue, describes it as â€œan inverse form of snobbery from people who have always been cynical of luxury fashion anywayâ€ â€“ but it is exacerbated by online discourse. â€œEveryoneâ€™s voice is amplified so now weâ€™re hearing more from the people that donâ€™t get [items such as the Ama],â€ says Chodha.

The wider news cycle is also a factor. â€œIâ€™m interested in whoâ€™s defending that shoe, and is it defendable,â€ says Chodha. â€œI wouldâ€™ve been that person a while ago but now with all of the wars happening around the world and all of the economic struggles that weâ€™re all going through, I just think this is a bit insane.â€

after newsletter promotion

Rodgers says the flatness of online exacerbates the reaction. â€œFashion is mediated mostly now through onscreen images,â€ he says. â€œIn the case of the Balenciaga Ikea shopping bag, you look at a picture of it on the screen and you think â€˜What? I can pick that up from Ikea for 75p!â€™, but what you donâ€™t see on screen is actually leather and it is actually made like a luxury item.â€

title: Escape Pod 932: The Walking Mirror of the Soul
excerpt: My desire was written all over Halcyonâ€™s torso, a shimmering tattoo composed of my thoughts and the Vonkraiâ€™s crusted skin.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Escape Pod 932: The Walking Mirror of the Soul

The Walking Mirror of the Soul

My desire was written all over Halcyonâ€™s torso, a shimmering tattoo composed of my thoughts and the Vonkraiâ€™s crusted skin.

{Tell VitÃ³ria you know.}

Luckily, we were alone in Teresa Stationâ€™s investigation room, so no one could read it. I was uneasy, palms sweating, tapping my feet on the floor. Normally, I met Vonkrai in restaurants, in the sightseeing deck or in the human-Vonkrai gatherings and conferences to restate our decade-long commercial and cultural partnership. In those places, their bodies were scrawled with everyoneâ€™s thoughts in a mess of unidentifiable and overlapping scribbles translated from human minds to Vonkrai bodies. Latin, Gujarati, Hangul, Cyrillic, Nsibidi, Arabic, and dozens of others from the Teresa Station human population. Mingled with our bulky and confusing thoughts, the Vonkraiâ€™s own dot-like script were scattered all over their bodies, words and logograms hopping from body to body, untraceable even for those who knew how to read Vonkraish.

But now, my mind glared back at me from their body like a damn accusation. It was hard to even follow the Detective 101 tips, like maintaining eye contact and interpreting body language. On the other hand, those things wouldnâ€™t really work with Vonkraiâ€”or they would be hard enough even for me, Isabela Cardoso, Teresa Stationâ€™s only investigator.

I tried to think about something else instead of my fiancÃ©eâ€”the case, think about the damn case youâ€™re being paid to solveâ€”so that those words were replaced, but they didnâ€™t shift. I shook my head and shifted my gaze from their body back to my comm-pad, skimming over the caseâ€™s file.

â€œHalcyon, can you repeat for the record what you saw in the market district?â€ Halcyon was my intervieweeâ€™s chosen Earth name. Each of them picked one for the health of our relationship, just as we picked aliases in their language.

â€œRepeating,â€ Halcyon said. I should be counting my blessings. Less than four percent of the Vonkrai had learned any of the Earthâ€™s languages, but Halcyon knew Portuguese. â€œA male human with a knife stabbed the victim, grabbed an object, ran.â€

I nodded, peeking at the picture of the dead man on my comm-pad. His mouth was puckered in revulsion, his eyes popped open in a frightened expression. JosÃ© Braga, a medical supplies vendor from Lorenzo Station who had recently acquired a stall in Teresa. Seemed like a simple case of robbery with homicide. Itâ€™d happened in the market district, where the off-station goods flowed in and out. And wherever there was money, there was greed; and where there was greed, there could be bodies. The only witness? Halcyon, who was crossing the district at the time to the quarters deck, where they spent half of each month.

â€œDid you say you were eating caldo verde at the time?â€ I said.

â€œAnswering: Yes.â€

I licked my lips. The environment module of Teresa was probably operating at lower levels of humidity. Or maybe I was getting nervous with the job (which wasnâ€™t common, but, hey, my fiancÃ©e had plans to move to Vladimir station and hadnâ€™t even told me about it, so I had the divine right of being overly sensitive).

â€œOkayâ€¦â€ I sighed. I peered into Halcyonâ€™s eyes, as if I could glean anything else from there. Nothing but the usual glint. Having evolved in the Goldilocks zone of their system, on a planet roughly the size of Earth with a similar atmosphere, the Vonkrai were like humans if you looked at them from a certain angle but extremely different if you looked from every other angle. They had our humanoid bodies as a distant resemblance, but theirs were rough like a stone and had a flinty periwinkle tonality, like an untouched vein of amethyst. Their eyes ranged from pitch to crystalline waters, their voices from whispers to drumbeats. Halcyon was a quiet one who spoke softly and hardly moved on the chair. If Halcyon were a human, Iâ€™d say they were extremely shy.

Notifications popped up in the corner of my padâ€™s screen. Twoâ€¦ Fiveâ€¦ Sevenâ€¦ Work time was work time, but only VitÃ³ria sent multiple messages in a row.

Escape Pod 931: The Rhythms of the World

The Rhythms of the World

As always, weâ€™re starving to death.

From our place inside the leather pouch tied to Aamsaaâ€™s belt, our two remaining stalks ache with hunger, barely able to hold our withered green-spotted spore caps upright. We reach down with whatâ€™s left of our network of hyphal tendrils, hoping to lap up any remaining contaminants from the patch of poisoned soil Aamsaa found last week, but thereâ€™s nothing left. No scraps of heavy metals or drops of industrial toxins. Weâ€™ve consumed it all. And if Aamsaa doesnâ€™t find more food for us soon, weâ€™re as good as dead.

What can we say? Toxic pollution isnâ€™t as easy to come by as it once was.

â€œWhat do you think?â€ we puff a cloud of message spores up to Aamsaa. â€œAre we going to make it this time? Or are you finally going to let us die in peace?â€

The irregular cadence of her arthritic gait grinds to a halt, and she scoffs.

â€œYouâ€™re the all-knowing, century-old fungus. Why donâ€™t you tell me?â€ she says, and there is a smug yet endearing confidence in her voice. She doesnâ€™t speak her strange, breathy human language. No, she speaks ours, the Rhythms of the World, the language of the soil and the sea and the sky with its low susurrations of air and fine chemical exchanges. Her human vocal cords and oil secretions arenâ€™t designed for the task, but that hasnâ€™t prevented her from mastering the nuances of the Rhythms over the decades.

â€œWeâ€™re not all-knowing,â€ we say.

â€œThen quit acting like it.â€

â€œHilarious. Now about that food?â€

â€œDonâ€™t get your caps in a twist.â€

With her knobbly knuckles, Aamsaa unknots the pouchâ€™s drawstring, and we release a puff of sensory spores to take in the damp, writhing sea-top mess that is the floating city of Del.

The night is cool with sea breeze as we stand on a wide, kelp-woven street lined with biomaterial buildings that resemble overgrown birdâ€™s nests. At the end of the street, an ancient steel wind tower looms, its blades and turbine long locked by rust and streaked with slashes of peeling white tar. The cylindrical tower is massive; and its numerous window boxes practically vomit plant life, thick with diverse ferns and dangling ivy. A latticework of vines grows aggressively up the bottom half of the tower, covered in globe-like flowers that crackle with a soft teal light. And then, about halfway up, the vines grow outward in an almost mycorrhizal pattern, spreading chaotically overhead and latching onto the roofs of each birdâ€™s nest building, forming a gently glowing canopy for the hundreds of humans milling in the street below.

â€œItâ€™s beautiful,â€ we say.

â€œDelâ€™s famous for its phyto-engineering,â€ Aamsaa says. â€œThe people in that tower have innovated some pretty impressive stuff. Theyâ€™ve set up tidal turbines beneath the city and trained those LumiVines to store and conduct electrical charges. Itâ€™s an ingenious distribution system.â€

Clouds of moths, each individual as large as one of Aamsaaâ€™s hands, flutter around the LumiVines, their translucent wings catching and refracting the light. We watch them sipping sap, careful to avoid the electricity stored within the flowers. Every now and then, one accidentally nicks a charged stamen, but with a quick buzzing Rhythm of protection, the electricity discharges harmlessly from the mothâ€™s body with a soft teal pop. Hidden by the darkness above, we hear the wing beats of storm gulls surveying the scene, eyeing the moths for a meal.

â€œYou see?â€ we say to Aamsaa, â€œWe could die here. It would be a pleasure to join with these Rhythms.â€

â€œI hate to be the bearer of bad news, but youâ€™re not going to die today. Listen.â€

Beneath the creaking of the concrete floats and rusted wind turbines upon which this city was grown, we hear it: a piercing, droning, ragged whistling, like a kettle that has nearly boiled through its water. An inexplicable Break in the Rhythms of the World coming from a nearby alley.

author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Escape Pod 930: Fulfillment in Purpose

Show Notes

Zima Blue episode of Love, Death & Robots

Ezekielâ€™s speech from The Walking Dead Season 8 Episode 4: And Yet I Smile

Fulfillment in Purpose

Eland was resetting his motherâ€™s balancing sculptures when Hexben ran in from the storage room. The robot tilted its long head down while still making eye contact, managing a look of consternation despite its rigid, expressionless face.

â€œWhat?â€ Eland snapped.

â€œYou should be packing those into boxes,â€ Hexben said without inflection. â€œOur lease ends next week.â€

â€œExactly,â€ Eland said. â€œIt doesnâ€™t end today.â€

Hexben deepened the tilt of its head so far that its chin touched its chest in a spot where the paint was well-worn away.

â€œOne big sale could change everything,â€ Eland said, looking back at his work. â€œWe could renew the lease for six months with a single sale.â€

Apparently satisfied with that response, Hexben returned to the storage room.

Carefully, Eland stacked the thin wooden rods one on top of the other, following the notches his mother had carved, each notch designed to match only one otherâ€”â€œa kiss between sticks,â€ sheâ€™d called it.

Once heâ€™d used all the sticks, he was left with a one-meter-high stack on which he began to hang delicate glass ornaments in a carefully orchestrated patternâ€”the same pattern heâ€™d followed daily for three years. An obsession born of grief and repetition had burned the pattern into his mind.

He was placing the final ornament when the front door to the shop opened, letting in a gust of wind. Eland grasped the structure to give it support against the blast, but he pushed too hard and the entire thing toppled down to the table. The sturdy ornaments bounced, didnâ€™t break, but that didnâ€™t stop a fury from rising in Eland as he looked toward the door.

â€œHexben! I told you never to open that door when Iâ€™m in the middleâ€”â€

It wasnâ€™t Hexben.

In the doorway stood a figure draped in a heavy shawl with a rebreather masking its face.

Tourists, thought Eland, so frightened by the silt outside that they would purchase anything branded as safety gear, no matter the markup.

The automatic disdain passed, allowing Eland to understand what he was seeing: a tourist. In his motherâ€™s gallery. A customer.

â€œHello!â€ he said with a broad smile on his face. The figure turned toward him and mumbled into its rebreather.

â€œNo silt in here,â€ Eland said, motioning to the ground. â€œPerfectly safe to remove your mask.â€

The figure nodded, then took off the mask with some difficulty. A young woman, about Elandâ€™s age if he had to guess, but it would only be a guess; hard to get a read on her under the face paint, which must now be fashionable in the quad-cities. Yellow and orange triangles sharpened her features, glowing against her dark skin and highlighting her auburn eyes.

â€œHow do people down here stand breathing through these things?â€ she asked in a tone frustrated but friendly.

Eland hadnâ€™t worn one since he was a child, but to spare her some embarrassment he kept that to himself. â€œYou get used to them.â€

â€œIâ€™m Mia.â€

â€œEland.â€

â€œIâ€™m so sorry for letting the wind in,â€ she said, looking at the mess in front of Eland. The expression on her face was a kind one. â€œWill you be able to fix it?â€

â€œNo problem, no problem,â€ he said, trying to keep any hint of frustration from seeping into his tone. â€œPlease, have a look around.â€

She smiled and began to walk around the studio, stopping here and there to examine some of the sculptures that hadnâ€™t toppled during her entrance.

Eland tried his best not to betray desperation when he asked, â€œAre you looking to buy?â€

She didnâ€™t turn from her inspections. â€œNot exactly. Iâ€™m a scout for the Intima Gallery on the orbital.â€

title: Escape Pod 929: The Library
excerpt: Every morning at ten to ten, Dot powered on. Its hands lay flat against the thick glass of the reading room window, which let the photoreceptors on its palms feast on the sun. The window overlooked a modest lot where cars had once parked in orderly fashion, side by side. Now tâ€¦
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Escape Pod 929: The Library

The Library

Every morning at ten to ten, Dot powered on. Its hands lay flat against the thick glass of the reading room window, which let the photoreceptors on its palms feast on the sun. The window overlooked a modest lot where cars had once parked in orderly fashion, side by side. Now the asphalt was veined with fissures, tufted with dandelions that had nudged and elbowed and bullied their way up from below.

Dot pulled its hands from the window. The synthetic skin suctioned off with a short, wet noise, one that Dotâ€™s colleague, Alex, would have described as rude. The sound echoed around the reading room and pinballed through the rows of empty shelves.

With nothing to reshelve or sort or alphabetize, the android defaulted to maintenance tasks: it swept the floor and carpet (no power, no vacuum); checksummed its internal library database (no updates since the Internet went down); dusted and wiped surfaces; checked the after-hours book drop, which was always emptyâ€”except for the time a mangy cat had climbed in through the slot. Dot named it Snowbell, from Stuart Little. For three days, the stray made the library its home, splitting its time between jumping across shelves and curling up into a tight ovoid for a nap. On the fourth morning, when no meows had greeted the day, Dot carried out a thorough search of the library before resigning itself to the fact Snowbell was gone.

Dot got a duster and headed for the stacks. The heart of the library was once crammed so tight with books that patrons often had trouble pulling out the titles they wanted. The bare shelves were now like the rib cage of a once-great leviathan, picked clean by scavengers to a dull, glaucous grey.

To reach the top shelf, Dot telescoped its legs, which made its skirt appear comically short; this had always made Alex snicker. It brushed the surface, spurring motes of dust into a languid ballet.

Its left elbow clicked. Not the first time this week. Dot had run several diagnostic scans, but they came back clean. Perhaps it was nothing. But if the issue was mechanical? That spelled trouble. Like a human, it couldnâ€™t kiss its elbow, much less repair it.

The android scanned itself again, but was interrupted by a muted thump-thump that reverberated through the library. It increased power to its hearing sensor. A few seconds later came a more insistent thump-thump-thump.

Someone was knocking on the front door.

The door had a top and bottom plexiglass pane separated by a thick middle rail. The upper pane was marred by three bullet fractals, left by an armed scavenger whoâ€™d come in the dead of winter, convinced there were still books inside and refusing to take no for an answer.

Now there stood a woman, hands cupped against the glass, framing her face as she peered inside the library.

â€œHi!â€ she said.

Dot assessed the patron. Two tight braids of red hair peeked out from under a black knit cap; streaks of dirt lined her angular and generously freckled face; her jacket was a high-end hiking raincoat with a strip of duct tape across the right arm; her jeans looked new, save for a large mud stain on the right knee. Her mismatched hiking boots gave Dot pause; this was atypical.

Behind the woman, Main Street was a bleak landscape: a doorless pick-up truck, a rusted shopping cart with missing front wheels, and the boarded-up yoga studio across the street, the plywood sheets warped from exposure to the elements.

â€œHey! Can you let me in?â€

â€œIâ€™m sorry,â€ Dot said, raising its voice to be heard through the door, â€œBut the library opens at eleven.â€

â€œOKâ€¦ So how soon is eleven?â€

â€œIn fifty-three minutes.â€

She smirked. â€œI guess Iâ€™ll wait.â€

The woman shrugged off her backpackâ€”it had thick shoulder straps and an external carbon-fibre frameâ€”and dropped it beside her.

She looked at Dotâ€™s forearm, where its model ID, .dewey, was tattooed. Alex, who well knew what the period represented, had playfully nicknamed it Dot.

â€œYouâ€™re a Cedalion Android, arenâ€™t you? Second Gen?â€

â€œCorrect. Decimal Dewey model.â€

title: Escape Pod 928: Zebulon Vance Sings the Alphabet Songs of Love (Flashback Friday)
excerpt: I am Robot!Ophelia. I will not die for love tonight.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Escape Pod 928: Zebulon Vance Sings the Alphabet Songs of Love (Flashback Friday)

Zebulon Vance Sings the Alphabet Songs of Love

I am Robot!Ophelia. I will not die for love tonight.

The noon show is the three-hour 1858 Booth production. The most fashionable historical war remains the First American Civil. Whenever FACfans discover that Lincolnâ€™s assassin played Horatio, they simply must come and gawk at this titillating replica of their favorite villain playing no oneâ€™s favorite character.

FACfans love authenticity. To the delight of Robot!Hamlet, todayâ€™s clients insist that Edwin Booth stride the stage beside his more famous brother. Most performances, Robot!Hamlet remains unused in the charging closet, for the first law in our business is Everybody Wants to Play the Dane.

Today, Robot!Hamlet is afire with Edwin Boothâ€™s mad vigor, and runs his improv algorithms at full throttle; he kisses me dreamily, and rips my bodice in a way that would never have been allowed in Victorian America. The FACfans donâ€™t look hyperpleased about this; it tarnishes their precious authenticity.

Robot!Horatio also loves the 1858 Booth. Itâ€™s the only time anyone comes to a performance for him alone. But what about the rest of us, the remainder of the AutoGlobeâ€™s incantation of robots? We bear with it, as we bear with all the other iterations of our native play.

The FACfans barely notice me when either Booth is on stage. I clutch my ripped bodice; exit Robot!Ophelia. I get me to a nunnery.

Act 4, Scene 4. I wait for my cue and check the callsheet for the six oâ€™clock show.

My next casting is for an Ophelia in the style of a vapid pop princess who died three hundred years ago. She was a terrible actress without a legacy, whose performance has been the low-water mark for Ophelias since first the play was the thing, and I canâ€™t even imagine what nostalgic hawk or handsaw has gotten up this customerâ€™s nose and made him choose that performance out of all the options on the menu.

Iâ€™ve wondered, but never asked, why that performance is even in my repertoire. I see no merit in a plastic recitation of the lines Iâ€™ve spoken one thousand, one hundred and sixty-eight times in the last year alone; no merit in wearing my hair perfectly combed during my madness; no merit in keeping my face expressionless in the way that was fashionable in twenty-first century New York, when even the youngest of women injected botulinum toxin into their facial muscles. Why recreate something that no one really missed in the end?

Scene 5 is here. My cue is coming. I sway onto center stage to deliver my rosemary and my remembrance.

When I return to the wings, I lie down to die. This is the indignity of Ophelia; I die for love, and yet my death is an after-thought, recited by the queen, and rarely staged. Your sisterâ€™s drownâ€™d, Laertes.

I cross my hands over my heart, waiting to be carried on-stage for the showing. No one needs me except in body; my thoughts are my own, and I am dreading six oâ€™clock. The next show is no act of avant-garde genius. Itâ€™s a straightforward reenactment of something dull and sad. Itâ€™s an indulgence in some artless cretinâ€™s obsessive fantasy with a woman who paid for her fame by dying young after living tackily.

And that is when I know. I will not die for love tonight.

I uncross my decorously folded hands. I get up. The play goes on in the background, the words slinking over my interlink from the AutoGlobeâ€™s other robots. I walk down to Wardrobe and head for Hamletâ€™s closet.

title: Ice cubes in beer: is this popular pub order atrocious â€“ or ingenious?
excerpt: Name: Icy beer.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Name: Icy beer.

Age: Niche for a while, now horribly mainstream.

Appearance: Thereâ€™s no way to sugarcoat this, itâ€™s beer with ice cubes in it.

I see weâ€™re talking about people with no taste today. If by people with no taste you mean 28% of all 18-35-year-olds, then yes.

To clarify: one in four adults under the age of 35 enjoy their beer with ice cubes in it? Slightly more than one in four, yes. But only when itâ€™s warm outside.

I have to say, this sounds like a lie. And yet there is undeniable proof of it, in the form of a survey of 2,000 people that was recently commissioned by LG.

The television manufacturing brand? That doesnâ€™t make it any less valid. Whatâ€™s more, thereâ€™s a good chance that the survey is conservative. The true number of icy beer fanatics is probably much higher.

Why is that? Because another 10% said embarrassment was holding them back from requesting ice in their beer, and another 20% said that they had previously been told off by friends, family and bar staff for requesting it.

Seriously, though, why is putting ice cubes in beer a bad thing? Because beer is already delicately flavoured enough as it is, so diluting it with melted ice risks rendering it tasteless. Plus, a lot of work went into crafting that flavour profile. Donâ€™t just mess it all up because you like your glass to clink when you swirl it.

Where did this horrible trend originate? France, apparently. In the southern regions, it is normal to do it on a hot day.

Even though TikTok is perpetually full of American people complaining about Franceâ€™s innate hatred of iced drinks? Listen, things change. People put ice cubes in beer. Itâ€™s progress.

This has to be the worst drinks trend of the year. Clearly someone hasnâ€™t seen Materialists yet.

Oh God, why? Because thatâ€™s the film where Dakota Johnson orders a drink thatâ€™s half beer and half Coca-Cola, known as a diesel in Germany.

What is happening to the world? Calm down. People drink shandies all the time, and thatâ€™s beer and lemonade. Whatâ€™s so bad about using a different fizzy drink?

I suppose that does make more sense than putting ice cubes in beer. Donâ€™t worry, this isnâ€™t actually going to be the future.

Whyâ€™s that? Because younger generations typically drink less than their older counterparts. And this, combined with the World Health Organizationâ€™s goal to reduce alcohol consumption by 20% per capita by 2030, means that drinking culture as we know it is on the verge of disappearing.

Oh fine, Iâ€™ll turn a blind eye this time. Thatâ€™s more like it. Barman, one half-beer, half-cola slushie, please.

Do say: â€œI put ice cubes in my beer to stay cool.â€

Donâ€™t say: â€œI prefer to submerge a baked potato in mine to make it more filling.â€

body:
Bad news for me: I turn 28 this week, and I donâ€™t feel particularly wiser. I do feel older, though. So, as you read this, you can be sure that I am probably quite drunk on sparkling wine. Thereâ€™s scarcely a better excuse than a birthday, but I think we can agree that what youâ€™re likely to be drinking at any such event will vary greatly, depending on whether or not the birthday in question is your own.

The Guardianâ€™s journalism is independent. We will earn a commission if you buy something through an affiliate link.Â Learn more.

Itâ€™s always good to start off with something sparkling, which is why, for the past few years, Iâ€™ve treated myself to a bottle of Billecart-Salmon in bed, but I think I might try something a bit different this year. My mind turns to Sip Champagnes, an independent, online retailer that connects consumers with the grower champagnes of the region. It even has a sub-Â£45 section, which, considering that many of the grandes marques are now pushing or exceeding Â£50 (eek!), provides a chance to taste something new for the same price or even less than usual.

Or, for even less, thereâ€™s crÃ©mant, which is basically for when youâ€™re having people over and buying en masse. CrÃ©mant is sparkling wine made in the same mÃ©thode traditonelle (traditional method) as champagne, during which the wine undergoes two fermentations to make it sparkling. An initial base wine is made and fermented into a dry wine, then, in a process known as tirage, yeast and sugar are added to kickstart a secondary fermentation, after which the wine is sealed with a crown cap.

This secondary fermentation creates COâ‚‚ (for the bubbles) and lees (spent yeast cells), which collect in the neck and give the wine its trademark biscuity flavour. These are then frozen and lifted off the top, at which point the bottle is sealed with the cork and cage we associate with sparkling wines. Itâ€™s the same method as champagne, but crÃ©mant costs far, far less.

Or how about something completely different? As I explored in a column earlier this year, fine sparkling cider is fast becoming my â€œwhy the hell not?â€ item for moments that demand marking with a coupe of something wonderful. â€œLike winemaking, correct terroir and climate are essential ingredients for fine cider-making,â€ says Nick Showering of Showerings Cider. â€œYou can blend vintages in a similar way to champagne to achieve a house style, and thatâ€™s something even the sommeliers at the likes of Lâ€™Enclume are now pouring.â€

And while cider certainly still has some catching up to do with champagne, I donâ€™t see why it canâ€™t be enjoyed in similar contexts. Swig it from the bottle in bed while opening your presents, or pour it into an oyster. Roll on 28.

author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Sri Lankaâ€™s favourite spirit, arrack, has a delicate flavour profile, and is created from toddy, the fermented sap of the coconut palmâ€™s flower. Tapped twice daily by toddy tappers, who expertly scale the palm trees, fermentation occurs naturally in handmade ceramic pots, before the arrack is distilled and lightly aged in native wood. It can be enjoyed in a variety of classic cocktails, including in a spritz or an ice-cold martini, as well as todayâ€™s frozen mule, which, with its revitalising kick of ginger and lime, is a great pick-me-up for a hot day.

Frozen arrack mule

Serves 1

50ml arrack â€“ we use Ceylon Arrack20ml fresh lime juice25ml ginger beer syrup â€“ mix 1:1 ginger beer to sugar and stir to dissolve (once made, itâ€™ll keep in the fridge for up to a week)1 thumb-sized piece fresh ginger, peeled and roughly chopped1 dash Angostura bitters 1 star anise, to garnish

Put everything bar the star anise in a high-speed blender, add a big handful of ice (crushed, ideally) and blitz smooth. Pour into a highball, sling or hurricane glass, drop in the star anise and serve with a straw.

title: Elegant, determined, a little unknowable: Giorgio Armani is gone but will never be forgotten
excerpt: Giorgio Armani dressed all of us. Whether or not you ever had the money for a jacket with an Armani label, you wore a jacket that he invented. He was the mastermind of contemporary style, the architect of how we dress now. If you have worn an unstructured suit with a T-shirt tâ€¦
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Giorgio Armani dressed all of us. Whether or not you ever had the money for a jacket with an Armani label, you wore a jacket that he invented. He was the mastermind of contemporary style, the architect of how we dress now. If you have worn an unstructured suit with a T-shirt to a wedding; if you have worn muted neutrals to work; if you have thought it might be chic to paint your living room grey: that was Armani.

Armani was working until his final days. Invitations had already been sent out for his next show, to be held on 28 September in the 14th-century courtyard of Milanâ€™s Palazzo Brera. A spectacular party to accompany the show was planned as a celebration of the 50th anniversary of the brand, which he founded in the summer of 1975.

On my phone I have dozens of videos of Armani taking catwalk bows at the end of his Milan ready-to-wear and Paris haute couture shows. For the past decade, everyone in the audience at each of his shows has been aware of being in the presence of a living legend. Each brief catwalk appearance has felt like a moment to capture, because even legends donâ€™t live for ever.

Those videos tell the story of a dignified, determined man, who even a decade ago, at 80, was taking bows in fitted navy T-shirts that showed off an impressive physique. In his last few years the walk became slower, the wave less muscular, but he was still immaculate.

At his January haute couture show in Paris, he wore a double-breasted black velvet tuxedo, smiling as he walked on the arm of a favourite model, blue eyes still piercing. In June and July this year, he was absent from his menswear and haute couture shows for the first time but oversaw fittings via video link from home, and corresponded with reporters over email.

Newspaper house style requires that we refer to him as Armani, but he was always Mr Armani, not just to the industry at large but to close colleagues. The fashion industry has long been a first-name-term world, even at the highest levels â€“ backstage, Donatella is Donatella, and Karl was Karl â€“ but the most commercially successful European fashion designer of the past century was never Giorgio, or even Armani, but always Signor or Mr Armani.

His persona was elegant, detached and a little unknowable. On the occasions when I interviewed him â€“ at his home in Milan, at Paris haute couture fashion week, and on his yacht, Mariu â€“ he was courteous and polite, an impeccably gracious host, but always with a note of reserve.

The Armani story begins with a suit. In the late 1970s, Armani took the trousersuit, filleted out all the stuffiness and tradition, and replaced it with a veneer of urbane sophistication and a spritz of louche sex appeal. In doing so, he reinvented power dressing for the late 20th century.

More than that, in fact: he redefined what it meant to look modern. Armani intuited how the once pin-sharp divisions between a starched world of work and a warm-slippered domestic bubble were already beginning to soften, in the 1970s and 1980s, even before the internet came along to annihilate them. His supple tailoring appealed to a generation who aspired to a different kind of success, who wanted to make it big but without losing their soul. They didnâ€™t want to get stuck in the same office until they earned their carriage clock, but rather to prowl and preen around the city.

As lifestyles shifted, Armani tailored a new silhouette to fit. â€œStyle for me is a mood that can be applied to everything,â€ he once said. â€œIâ€™ve always thought fashion is much more than just clothes: it is a way of being.â€ An Armani suit made a new generation feel like big beasts of the urban jungle. If you aspired to be an architect or an actor or a media hustler or an agent, this suit spoke to who you wanted to be. He took the suit, which had been stuck in the 9-to-5, and gave it both street smarts and bedroom appeal.
