title: Giorgio Armani obituary
excerpt: In the 1970s, the fashion designer Giorgio Armani, who has died aged 91, anticipated two permanent and interdependent cultural shifts: the rise in the cult of the gym, which made every manâ€™s physique his own responsibility, rather than a tailorâ€™s; and the end of constriction iâ€¦
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
In the 1970s, the fashion designer Giorgio Armani, who has died aged 91, anticipated two permanent and interdependent cultural shifts: the rise in the cult of the gym, which made every manâ€™s physique his own responsibility, rather than a tailorâ€™s; and the end of constriction in menâ€™s clothing.

Even before he showed his first collection, in 1975, Armani had been challenging ideas about the male suit and overcoat as they had been constructed since the 1790s â€“ on a basis of stiff canvas, interlining, padding and special stitching, so as to reshape a manâ€™s torso to look as much as possible like a classical statue. He discardedÂ this armature that helped hide imperfections. And when he draped a fluid suede jacketÂ on the toned body of Richard Gere in the 1980 movie American Gigolo, he finally knocked the stuffing out of tailoring. It has never quite returned.

Armani said of the filmâ€™s core, man-chooses-what-to-wear sequence: â€œThe magical moment, where the shirts are on the bed and Gere throws the ties on the shirt, was so right for the time. It was about his choices, his muscles; it was throwing away the whole story of the way men dress.â€

Armani was just as revolutionary when he offered female professionals the same boneless structure as men, at a time when a suit, trousered or skirted, was becoming an almost obligatory uniform for working women. His gentler power dressing was the easiest female working gear since Coco Chanel invented her tweed suit in 1954. He explained: â€œI always tried to eliminate the things that made women appear like a caricature of themselves.â€

Armaniâ€™s success was particularly Italian, a product of the city of Milan, where he worked with textiles for years before he used his knowledge of them for design. The Italian clothing industry could weave, cut and sew high-quality products, but it had lacked international prestige, and was willing to support designers who might supply that. Armani took its cloth and leather, and tapped its skills, especially new ready-to-wear manufacturing techniques that could simulate the flexibility in movement of handwork. For the rest of his life he reinvested in Milan, where his base and heart remained, as its duke of fashion.

He was not to the palazzo born, although his taste for ascetic luxury was evident early; he attributed it to his mother, Maria (nee Raimondi), and her â€œsense of taking things away, of being minimalâ€. Materially, there was not much to subtract â€“ as the wife of Ugo Armani, who worked for a transport company, she brought up Giorgio and his siblings, Sergio and Rosanna, in wartime Piacenza, south of Milan, doing without herself in order to dress them well in hard times. Armani remembered all her few dresses, and she remained his confidante into her 90s. He was intrigued by his grandfatherâ€™s wigmaking for the theatre, too, and developed his own imagination staging puppet shows and watching movies. So far, so Cinema Paradiso.

Armani left for military service, and studied at medical school, but outgrew his ambition to be a doctor. He got a window-dresserâ€™s job in 1957 at the Milanese department store La Rinascente, then took charge of its fabrics. Ignorant of fashion, unable to draw, but simpatico with cloth, he was hired by the menswear firm Nino Cerruti to manage its textiles in 1964, then moved into design; he went freelance in 1970.

At Cerruti, he met Sergio Galeotti, who became his partner in love and business; together they set up a company in 1975, selling Armaniâ€™s old VW Beetle to fund their tiny office. â€œWe didnâ€™t have a lot of experience,â€ said Armani, â€œbut we had energy.â€ Galeotti gave Armani confidence; he managed sales, flying to the US to dictate Armaniâ€™s terms, and all finances so completely that Armani did not even need to carry a wallet.

Escape Pod 938: Chug the Tea Leaves, Chuck the Ads

Chug the Tea Leaves, Chuck the Ads

I wake up to a message and a certain intuition that my first ad of the day will be for Bubble Fresh.

I can almost see it, flashing through my MindzEye, just in time for me to grab a pack at the newsstand. Bubble Fresh Gum on my morning commute always means it will be a good day. The question is what kind of good, and the answer is in the flavor: Spearmint for promotion, Juicymint for romance.

Last night, against the odds, Joleen unghosted me. This morning I hope for Juicymint.

The ad arrives. Iâ€™m still on the subway. Itâ€™s early, which isnâ€™t good, but not necessarily bad. Itâ€™s a brand Iâ€™ve never heard of, with a name I canâ€™t even pronounce. For a second I still think what Iâ€™m seeing might be gum; just unwrapped and pre-chewed.

But then I read the copy and I see that itâ€™s about as far from gum as you can get while I guess still being roughly the same shape. I donâ€™t think itâ€™s meant for eating but I was hoping so badly for gum that I imagine cracking it between my teeth, shards and splinters piercing my cheeks.

I stop, mid-stride through the car doors. People push past. I search the ad for clues, like I was taught. I miss the bing-bong, and the doors close and crush my backpack and for a second I am paralyzed, soon to be torn apart by the pull of my feed and the perpendicular pull of the car down the platform.

The doors open again. I blink the ad away, ignore the ire of my fellow passengers. When I reply to Joleen my hands are shaking. I walk right past the newsstand, relieved to see that it is closed today, no gum anyway, as if this might explain it all away.

My relief is brief. The ads do not abate.

By the time I get to work Iâ€™ve blinked another dozen or so away. I do my best to ignore them, but then a particularly gnarly one appears during our daily stand-up and I canâ€™t help it, I gasp, loud enough to stop the meeting in its tracks.

â€œBad ads,â€ Tod mumbles, sagely, like Iâ€™m just another corporate greenhorn. He likes to wrangle greenhorns, it shores up his own position. Heâ€™ll tell me what I already know, and if or when I cleanse myself, heâ€™ll take some credit.
Iâ€™m not green, not anymore. Iâ€™ve been climbing the floors for eight years. Iâ€™ve gone up and up (and briefly down) and up. I can handle a bad ad or two.

But these ads arenâ€™t just bad. Theyâ€™re weird. Indecipherable.

Even, maybe, dare I say itâ€”sinister. When I close my eyes I get the (irrational, technologically impossible) feeling that these ads could pierce the barrier of my eyelids, and from there take the open highway to my brain, my dreams.
Obviously I donâ€™t say any of this to Tod. He ends the meeting early, clears the room like itâ€™s a confessional and heâ€™s my priest. Or, more likely, itâ€™s a quarantine and heâ€™s isolating me from the others in case my ads are contagious.

â€œYou know where you gotta go,â€ he says.

â€œI know, Tod.â€

â€œYou gotta go to my man Rito.â€

Every tech exec on every floor north of ten knows where to turn when their feed goes south.

â€œRitoâ€™s a mad lad,â€ Tod says. â€œHeâ€™s the guy you need if you gotta read the future in your ads.â€

I take the elevator down to street level, scrolling down the feed of Tower Town. Tod took me here almost two years ago to meet Rito after a particularly bad ad.

â€œIâ€™m too smart to believe in God,â€ Tod said, like I wasnâ€™t already on board. â€œI put my faith in that other Almighty, the algorithm. The algo predicts your future; God can only forgive your past.â€

f*** that, it wasnâ€™t really Lacunaâ€™s baby. It wasnâ€™t her idea. The idea was Redâ€™s.

Escape Pod 936: Old Peopleâ€™s Folly (Part 2 of 2)

Old Peopleâ€™s Folly (Part 2 of 2)

(â€¦Continued from Part 1)

Kite was still curled into a bundle of blankets in front of the stove when Setti woke. The old woman sniffed, torn between surprise and annoyance. Sheâ€™d have figured him for a quitter, sneaking out before dawn to escape the work. Thatâ€™s what sheâ€™d have done when she was his age. Not like Setti was in any shape to chase after him. But heâ€™d stayed and now she was stuck with him, just like she was stuck with her ghost. There was a thought to cheer her up in the morning.

â€œEy, boy.â€

The bundle of blankets stirred, then Kite woke with a start. The bruise on his face looked worse in the harsh morning light, his cheek all swollen and purple. From the way he winced, it wasnâ€™t the only one either. Setti dropped a bowl of oats on the table for him.

â€œAbout time you start working for your food.â€

She didnâ€™t stick around to see if he would eat and instead snagged the ghost disk on her way out the door. The last thing she needed was the boy messing around with it. Her knee twinged in protest, objecting to yesterdayâ€™s treatment just like it did every day. Setti didnâ€™t have the luxury to heed her bodyâ€™s constant objections.

It barely took five minutes before Kite emerged as well, still mute as a butterfly. Setti put the axe into his hand and pointed him at the pear tree, then shuffled off to plant some beans. To her surprise it didnâ€™t take long for the tell-tale sound of the axe to start up. Maybe the boy would actually manage to strip the tree of its gnarled branches before he winged it. Maybe he was more than a pretty voice. Setti shook her head. Shouldnâ€™t get too optimistic. Maybe the ghost had made her go soft with her ideals and her talk of change.

With a grunt Setti settled onto the ground next to her vegetable bed. Sheâ€™d tried a thousand different ways of planting seeds while bending down and none of them had worked with a bad knee. Sitting in the dirt wasnâ€™t pretty, but it did the trick and if she had it her way there wouldnâ€™t be anyone around to see.

The sound of chopping stopped after a suspiciously short amount of time.

â€œMs. Setti?â€ There was a strange look on Kiteâ€™s face, excitement warring with confusion. His voice was still quiet, almost inaudible, as if he were ashamed to admit its existence.

â€œWhat? Broke something already?â€ The reply came out harsher than Setti had intended. She didnâ€™t like it when people caught her helpless and there wasnâ€™t much that screamed helplessness as loudly as crawling on the ground like a beetle on its back. Kite hunched his shoulders, but his expression didnâ€™t waver. He must have a shitty family if this kind of answer was business as usual for him.

â€œThere are bees.â€ Setti rolled her eyes, but of course the boy wasnâ€™t finished. â€œUp in one of the trees. A whole bunch of them.â€

With an unhappy grunt Setti groped for her cane. Bad weather for swarming bees, too cold, too windy, though obviously that fact hadnâ€™t gotten around to her swarm. The old woman grabbed the handle of her cane and miserably botched her first two attempts at getting up. The pain in her knee brought tears to her eyes. At least Kite had the good grace to look away and pretend not to notice. Not like the millerâ€™s son, who offered Setti his arm every time she went down to the village as if it were a courtesy to rub into her face how frail she was.

Escape Pod 935: Old Peopleâ€™s Folly (Part 1 of 2)

Old Peopleâ€™s Folly (Part 1 of 2)

Setti knew the woman for a ghost the moment she appeared. It was the pink hair that gave her away, short and spiky. Real people didnâ€™t have hair like that. Also, you couldnâ€™t see the scratchmarks on Settiâ€™s kitchen table through real peopleâ€™s torsos.

â€œThe hell?â€ was the first thing the ghost said. Settiâ€™s grandfather had tried to tell her ghost stories when she was a kid, a long time ago, but heâ€™d had a habit of smoking and drinking too, so none of the stories had ever made any sense and Setti didnâ€™t like unannounced visitors.

â€œGet out of my house,â€ Setti demanded.

â€œUm,â€ the ghost answered, staring at Setti with her eyes rimmed in thick black mascara, then held holding up a placating hand. â€œOkay. Just let me findâ€”â€

The ghost blinked out of existence.

Setti poked at the shiny silver disk with the tip of her mussel knife. There was nowhere else the ghost could have come from. Sheâ€™d found the disk down at the beach while foraging for mussels, half buried in a mudslide but gleaming with a smoothness and lack of rust only pre-flood things ever retained. One more thing unearthed by the storm. It hadnâ€™t been a bad storm, as they went, not tearing-down-houses strong. Plenty strong to bring down the pear tree behind Settiâ€™s house, though. Setti sniffed. Shame it hadnâ€™t been the apple tree. She held a severe dislike for apple trees.

Setti had planned on bartering away the disk at the next market fair. Always some dumb folks about, paying for useless curiosities. She poked it again for good measure, with no more reaction than the first time. Some people might even pay more for the ghost living inside it, but Setti wasnâ€™t sure it was worth the trouble. Maybe she should toss it back onto the beach. She glared at the disk some more without reaching a decision, then turned away to grab her cane. Wasnâ€™t like the ghost would help with planting beans or checking on her bees or getting rid of the tangle of branches and pear blossoms now blocking the back garden. She grimaced getting up, her bad knee twinging. Folk used to say you could feel a storm coming with a knee like this. The way her knee usually screamed in agony Setti figured there should have been a storm every day the last forty-five years, or maybe she simply hadnâ€™t figured out the difference between the pain announcing bad weather and the pain telling her sheâ€™d run out of willow bark tea.

Setti hesitated in the doorway, then hobbled back to snatch up the disk and put it in her satchel. She didnâ€™t want the ghost to get any ideas, slipping out of its home and into some of Settiâ€™s furniture while she wasnâ€™t looking. Who knew what ghosts might set their mind to?

Hauling up water from the well was always a pain with her bad knee. Surprising how many things you needed a painless limb for, not that Setti bothered with surprise any more. She staggered inside with a bucket of water, dumped the mussels into it so they wouldnâ€™t spoil until evening, then left the ghost disk on a stack of firewood under the eaves before checking on her bees. Bees got angry about the strangest things, so better not risk it.

The bees were fine, still hunkering down after the storm. All the hives had survived without damage this time. Setti didnâ€™t even bother slipping on gloves for opening the hive boxes. The bees had been furious before the storm, bad weather always got their temper up, but now they buzzed placidly, almost sluggish in the chilly breeze. When Setti returned to the house the ghost was floating in the yard.

â€œFigured this didnâ€™t count as your house.â€ She smirked.

â€œGet lost, ghost,â€ Setti said. â€œI donâ€™t have the patience for the likes of you today.â€

â€œIâ€™m not a ghost,â€ the ghost protested with indignation.

The Alien in My Bathtub

The alien in my bathtub refused to leave. It was there when I returned to my apartment in Ring B. It ignored me when I asked it to vacate the premises, and when I enquired as to how it had entered my apartment it replied with a dismissive grunt. I had no intention of trying to remove it by physical force, which would have gone against the most basic rules of human-alien etiquette. And, to be honest, I didnâ€™t want to touch it. So, I called Station Relations. I waited and watched as the spindly creature splashed around. The water was greasy and tinted green with the entire contents of the luxury exfoliating scrub I had ordered from Earth a week ago, at no small expense.

I didnâ€™t know what the creature was or where it came from. It wasnâ€™t a species from the Systems Trade Alliance, and no one had informed me or my team that this particular specimen was coming aboard the station. It was skinny and snouted, like a hairless dog from Peru or Mexico, but bipedal judging by its form and movements. Its skin was leathery, a mottled brown. Its four wiry limbs ended in short, slender fingers, four digits on each hand or paw. Between its legs hung a lengthy, narrow and flaccid penis that flopped around in the water. It might have been a tail. I hoped it was a tail.

The alien paid me little attention. It glanced at me when I first entered the bathroom, then resumed its splashing while singing in a series of squeaks and belches.

â€œExcuse me,â€ I repeated, with more force this time. Nothing. It just sat in my tub, eating my bar of Martian Dew soap.

The door chimed. â€œCome in,â€ I said and I walked to the living room.

A woman entered. She was a little younger than me, I guessed, early thirties. Her sky-blue uniform was immaculate, her brown hair pulled back into a tight bun. â€œGemma Stine, Station Relations,â€ she said, without offering her hand. â€œMr. Balta, correct?â€

â€œYes. Thanks for coming so quickly. Itâ€™s through here.â€

She followed me to the bathroom and observed the bathing alien. It ignored us. â€œYou said you came back from work and it was there, in the water?â€ said Stine.

â€œExactly. I run VIP hospitality in Ring B.â€

â€œI know who you are,â€ she said, which normally would have pleased me, but the indifference in her voice sounded almost like spite. She must have had her share of run-ins with the rich and powerful â€”humans, mainlyâ€”who frequented the stationâ€™s exclusive VIP zones, so I could understand her disinterest, perhaps even disdain, for my position. I loved my job, I was proud of itâ€”I had worked my way up from station stray to cabin boy to head of hospitality. But the people I served, the wealthy, the dignitaries, the decision makers, the ClubSol card holders, well, they typically chose caviar and complaints over kindness.

â€œDo you know what it is?â€ I asked.

â€œItâ€™s a Volon.â€ She unclipped a mini portable from her belt and pointed it at the alien. â€œIâ€™ll scan it.â€ Her portable bleeped as the creature splashed around. It dunked its head under the water and blew a stream of bubbles. Stine put a finger to her ear and listened to the scan results. â€œSir, are you sure you didnâ€™t invite it in?â€

â€œOf course not. Why would Iâ€”â€

Escape Pod 933: Summitting the Moon

Summitting the Moon

T-7 days

The moon Landed, the Rut appeared, home equity plummeted, jobs disappeared, and Ghis liked riding the moon. It was the last item on this tragic list that her wife couldnâ€™t accept. It was the leaf that broke the whaleâ€™s back or something similar.

â€œItâ€™s the last time, Max,â€ Ghis said. â€œI promise.â€

Max rolled her eyes and blew cigarette smoke out the window. The pungent vapor followed the wind back into the house a second later. On another night years ago, Max had stood at that window on a full moon night with the light caressing her profile as she looked out at the landscape with a hopeful expression. But there were no more moonlit nights, and Max was no longer the hopeful woman Ghis once knew.

â€œIâ€™m not lying this time,â€ Ghis said.

Disappointment was etched deep like glacier-carved mountains on Maxâ€™s face. Some of this was her fault, Ghis admitted, but surely, the moon took most of the blame.

â€œWe could have left so long ago,â€ Max said. Ghis caught the shine on her cheeks before Max wiped it away.

â€œThis is the absolute last run. Iâ€™ll sell the speeder, the suitâ€”everything,â€ Ghis insisted. Fear shot through her body at the mention of selling her prized possessions.

â€œWhy did you do it? Why did you join the Flight Club and get in on this nonsense? Andâ€¦ for the record, such a stupid name,â€ Max turned to Ghis, her face set like stone. â€œHave you even watched the movie? Itâ€™s a satire!â€

â€œIt was named ironically,â€ Ghis said in a quiet voice.

Max glared at her.

â€œYou may not be in the club anymore, Ghisara. But those people are what got you started on thisâ€¦ this addiction,â€ Max strode up to her so they were face to face. Her anger was easier to handle at a distance. This close, it was provoking.

â€œAn addiction? What about your smokes? Have you given up? No more motherhood for you, I guess,â€ Ghis retorted. It was a low blow. Ghis thought she saw Max flinch, a crack in her rigid demeanor.

Max sauntered up to the free off-the-sidewalk dining table they got the first year of their relationship. She brought the cigarette up to Ghisâ€™s face, and waved it tauntingly. Ghis rubbed her nose so she wouldnâ€™t sneeze from the combination of smoke and moondust allergies. Max crushed the remaining cigarette into the table and Ghis winced as the coal stain marked itself on the furniture.

â€œTell you what. You make this your last run and Iâ€™ll make this my last smoke,â€ Max said with a smirk.

And then? Her heart pounded as she waited for her wifeâ€™s next words like she was waiting for a judgeâ€™s verdict.

â€œAnd in a weekâ€™s time, we move out of the fucking Rut Zone. and then finally,Â  finally start a life together after.â€ Maxâ€™s eyes didnâ€™t leave hers. â€œDeal?â€

Ghis swallowed. Her promise would have to be real this time. This would be her last and only run. She didnâ€™t have it in her to lose the only woman she loved over seeing the big blue.

â€œDeal,â€ Ghis mumbled.

Max pecked her on the cheek. â€œGood, well you better get back to your shed, miss moon rider. Hope this one goes well for your sake.â€

Ghis moved the dinner plates from the table to the sink and attempted to wipe the cigarette stain off the table. The mark did not budge no matter how much she scrubbed; it was going to stay, just like the Rut. Ghis looked out the window towards it. There was nothing but a vast expanse of land, dotted with shrubs and lined with short scraggly trees. As land approached the horizon, it disappeared, a void that dipped before merging with the night sky.

T-4 days

Ghis was three days into polishing her speeder and checking her engine software when she realized that sheâ€™d already done everything she could to get ready. Max, on the other hand, packed like sheâ€™d been waiting her whole life for this move.

The salsa is best made just before serving, so prep and chop everything and keep it separately in the fridge, if need be (though you could chop and mix the onion with the lime in advance).

title: Sandwich surprise! 12 delicious â€“ and diabolical â€“ ways to sweeten your sarnie
excerpt: Tescoâ€™s recently introduced birthday cake sandwich â€“ an unholy assemblage of jam, soft cheese, frosting and sprinkles, stuffed between two slices of brioche â€“ may well be the worldâ€™s most depressing foodstuff, a cake designed to be eaten in one go, possibly on your birthday, pâ€¦
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Tescoâ€™s recently introduced birthday cake sandwich â€“ an unholy assemblage of jam, soft cheese, frosting and sprinkles, stuffed between two slices of brioche â€“ may well be the worldâ€™s most depressing foodstuff, a cake designed to be eaten in one go, possibly on your birthday, probably alone.

The birthday cake sandwich follows hard on the heels of M&Sâ€™s strawberries and cream sandwich â€“ a UK version of the fruit sandwiches, or furutsu sandos, sold in convenience stores in Japan. The M&S sandwich received a certain amount of criticism, along with some surprisingly good reviews. But both sandwiches were controversial, not least from a nutritional standpoint (the Tesco sandwich contains 31.5g of sugar, over a third of the recommended maximum daily intake for an adult), but also because they upset our notion of what a sandwich is. Arenâ€™t they supposed to be savoury? Arenâ€™t they supposed to be lunch, rather than dessert?

Bur sweet sandwiches are not uncommon â€“ anything with jam in it counts â€“ and the sandwich itself is not a rules-based enterprise: itâ€™s more of a continuous trial-and-error process â€“ even as you eat a sandwich youâ€™ve just made, youâ€™re thinking about how it could be better next time. When it comes to sweet fillings, youâ€™ve got to try at least a few before you reject them out of hand. Here are 12 ideas to get you started.

A note: most sweet sandwiches do not require a recipe, and are subject to endless modification. Feel free to experiment with different breads, flavours and proportions â€“ you may as well have it the way you want it.

First up, a deep-fried peanut butter and jelly (clear jam) sandwich, from food blogger Davie Leite at the website Leiteâ€™s Culinaria. Arguably, the classic PB&J is already a sweet sandwich â€“ but the addition of a sugary deep-fried batter turns this humble childhood treat into the kind of snack that helped kill Elvis. The recipe offers two extra options I immediately rejected: sliced banana (no thank you) and a white chocolate ganache for dipping (are you kidding?).

A sturdy sourdough bread is recommended. I might have sliced it a little too thick â€“ of no consequence taste wise, but it makes it harder to fry. Be careful not to go overboard with the fillings. Slap it together as you normally would, dip the whole thing into the batter, and deep fry it in hot oil, flipping once.

If youâ€™re looking for rare examples of foodstuffs that are not improved by deep-frying, you can start here. You could tinker with proportions all day and still not make something palatable out of this heavy, greasy, sticky mess. In case it was just me, I forced some on my oldest son, who simply shook, went quiet, then said, no.

Other sweet fried sandwiches include the grilled Nutella banana sandwich, a grilled Nutella and marshmallow sandwich and the banana french toast sandwich. The classic Monte Christo sandwich, while technically savoury (itâ€™s ham and cheese on french toast), is traditionally served in the US dredged in icing sugar, with jam. As an American, I apologise.

The Japanese strawberry and cream sandwich â€“ or ichigo sando â€“ on which M&S based its version, is easy enough to recreate at home. Just watch recipe developer Marc Matsumoto. I substituted brioche slices for the authentic Japanese milk bread: itâ€™s easier to find.

First, carefully wash, top and dry your strawberries â€“ five per sandwich. Whip a generous quantity of double cream, sweeten to taste and set aside.

The final key component in this recipe is strawberry jam â€“ spread a thin layer on both bread slices and heap the whipped cream on top in shallow pyramids. On one half push your largest strawberry into the centre of the cream and then position four more round it, pointy ends facing the corners of the bread.

author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
A low-effort dessert inspired by cafÃ© de olla, which is a drink I consumed daily while on holiday in Oaxaca, Mexico. Itâ€™s a black coffee gently spiced with cinnamon and cloves, and sweetened with piloncillo (an unrefined sugar). Here, Iâ€™ve turned it into something refreshing for summer, using dark brown sugar instead, not least because itâ€™s easier to find. I can never resist a post-dinner coffee, and this scratches both that caffeine and sugar itch.

Spiced coffee granita with whipped cream

Prep 5 min
Cook 15 min, plus cooling
Freeze 2 hr 30 min+
Serves 4

500ml freshly brewed coffee, or espresso
1 stick cinnamon
3 cloves
75g dark brown sugar
120ml double cream
Pinch of flaky sea salt

Pour the coffee into a small pan, add the cinnamon, cloves and sugar and heat gently until it comes to a simmer. Leave to simmer for five minutes, until the sugar dissolves and the mixture starts smelling fragrant. Take off the heat, leave to cool completely, then strain into a shallow, freezer-friendly container.

Freeze the mixture for an hour, then mix it with a fork and return to the freezer for 20-30 minutes. Mix again to break up the ice crystals, then repeat this process two to three times more, until you have lots of crystals.

Lightly whip the double cream with a pinch of flaky salt. To serve, spoon the granita into small glasses and top each one with a dollop of cream.

title: Helen Gohâ€™s recipe for honey and almond semifreddo with nectarines | The sweet spot
excerpt: Softer and lighter than ice-cream, semifreddo, which is Italian for â€œhalf-coldâ€ or â€œhalf-frozenâ€, is also easier to make because it doesnâ€™t need churning. Customise this one by swapping the almonds for pistachios, and serving it with cherries or other seasonal fruit. Do seek oâ€¦
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Softer and lighter than ice-cream, semifreddo, which is Italian for â€œhalf-coldâ€ or â€œhalf-frozenâ€, is also easier to make because it doesnâ€™t need churning. Customise this one by swapping the almonds for pistachios, and serving it with cherries or other seasonal fruit. Do seek out the anise seeds, though, because they add such a lovely pop of flavour. The praline can be made up to a week ahead and stored in an airtight container in the freezer, while the semifreddo itself will keep happily in the freezer for about a week.

Honey and almond semifreddo with nectarines

Prep 5 min
Cook 1 hr 15 min
Freeze Overnight
Serves 8

For the praline90g sugar

70g whole roasted almonds
Pinch of sea salt

Pinch of sea salt

For the semifreddo5 egg yolks 20g runny honey 80g caster sugar

, lightly toasted and crushed in a mortar
2 egg whites
300ml double cream
1 tsp anise seeds

2 egg whites

300ml double cream

1 tsp anise seeds

For the nectarines
2 tsp caster sugar
2 tsp lemon juice
2 tsp runny honey
A pinch of salt
4 ripe nectarines1 sprig fresh basil or mint, leaves roughly torn

Line a baking tray with greaseproof paper and set aside. To make the praline, put the sugar and 30ml water in a small saucepan and set it over a low heat. Stir until the sugar dissolves, then turn up the heat to medium-high and cook, without stirring but swirling the pan occasionally, until the mix turns a deep golden colour. Stir in the almonds, then pour on to the lined tray, sprinkle with sea salt and leave to cool and harden. Once hardened, break up the praline, then pulse in a food processor (or bash with a rolling pin) to break down into small, irregular pieces no larger than 1cm. Store in an airtight container in the freezer until needed.

Line the base and sides of a 10cm x 20cm loaf tin with greaseproof paper, leaving a generous overhang to help you lift the semifreddo out later. Fill a medium saucepan a third of the way up with water and bring to a simmer. In a medium heatproof bowl, whisk the egg yolks, honey and 40g sugar, then set the bowl over the pan, ensuring the base isnâ€™t touching the water. Whisk for six to eight minutes, until thick and pale, then take off the heat and whisk (ideally over a bowl of ice) until cooled.

Put the egg whites in the bowl of an electric mixer and whisk until white and foamy. Gradually beat in the remaining 40g sugar, whisking until it dissolves and the mix comes to firm peaks. Scrape the meringue into the egg yolk bowl, but donâ€™t mix it in just yet.

In the same bowl and with the same whisk attachment (no need to wash them), whip the cream to soft peaks. Scrape this into the yolk bowl, too, then add the anise seeds and praline, and fold until just combined. Scrape the mixture into the lined tin, smooth the top and freeze overnight (or for up to a week).

About 30 minutes before serving, prepare the nectarines. In a medium bowl, whisk the sugar, lemon juice, honey and salt. Halve and stone the nectarines, then cut them into 1cm wedges. Toss with the syrup and herbs, then leave to macerate.

To serve, lift the semifreddo out of its tin using the overhang, then cut into roughly 2Â½cm-thick slices. Arrange on plates, spoon the nectarines on top and serve at once.

title: Sticky end? The British pudding faces extinction, English Heritage warns
excerpt: At the end of the 17th century a French travel writer who crossed the Channel was clearly impressed by the sweet, comforting treats offered to him, declaring with relish: â€œAh! What an excellent thing is an English pudding!â€
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
At the end of the 17th century a French travel writer who crossed the Channel was clearly impressed by the sweet, comforting treats offered to him, declaring with relish: â€œAh! What an excellent thing is an English pudding!â€

More than three centuries on, English Heritage has sounded the alarm that the good old British pudding is facing extinction.

Research from the charity suggests two-thirds of households in England, Wales and Scotland make puddings only once a month or less, while a third never bake or boil or steam one.

English Heritage warned that if nothing was done to stem the tide, the great British pudding will not exist in 50 years.

Dr Andrew Hann, a senior curator of history at English Heritage, said: â€œSweet puddings are closely intertwined with British history and it would be a huge shame for them to die out.â€

For the purposes of this research, the charity defines puddings as cooked sweet courses that follow a main meal â€“ so not just traditional â€œpuddingsâ€ typically made in mould or basins but also dishes such as apple pies or crumbles.

Hann waxed lyrical about the sort of puddings his mother would make. â€œShe regularly produced a delicious pudding after the main course â€“ things like steamed sponge pudding with coming out of a pudding basin with the syrup dribbling down the side. There was a whole repertoire of delicious puddings. People are not generally making these sort of hot desserts but turning to things like ice-cream, yoghurts or fruit.â€

English Heritage said recipes for sweetened meat pies from the medieval period had been found and that by the Tudor and Stuart times, puddings sweetened with honey or fruit were common, although many would also have contained meat.

Hann said puddings were once a luxury for the well-off but as sugar became more widely available, more people could enjoy them. The 20th century was probably the heyday of the British pudding.

â€œHowever, the research shows a clear shift away from the traditional dessert over the past 50 years,â€ Hann said. â€œAs more women entered the workforce from the 1970s onwards, households no longer had as much time to cook and started to prioritise convenience. If this decline continues, we can expect the classic great British pud to all but vanish within the next 50 years.â€

The research, which was carried out by YouGov, found 2% of British households eat a daily homemade pudding.

While half of people born before 1970 said their parents made puddings several times a week, that was the case for only 26% of those born in the 1970s. The downward trend has continued since then.

In an attempt to reignite Britainâ€™s love affair with puddings, English Heritage has introduced two new pudding-inspired ice-cream flavours to its sites: sticky toffee and apple crumble and custard.

The charity is also launching The English Heritage Baking Book in early September. It contains recipes for all the nationâ€™s favourite puddings but also some of the forgotten ones, accompanied by notes on their history.

skip past newsletter promotion

after newsletter promotion

Four British classics at risk

Twelfth Night cakeBy the reign of Elizabeth I, Twelfth Night involved a celebratory cake, typically a rich, yeasty fruit bread flavoured with spices, and a token or bean hidden inside. The person who found the bean became the Lord of Misrule or King of the Bean, and would have to organise the eveningâ€™s revelry. The cake survived the Reformation. People began to use eggs to raise the cake, and as sugar and fruit came down in price, the cake became less of a fruited bread and more like a rich fruit cake. Over time, it was replaced by the Christmas cake.

Soul cakeAlso know as a soulmass-cake, they were traditionally given to children or poorer people, known as â€œsoulersâ€, who would go from door to door singing songs or reciting prayers over Allhallowtide (Halloween, Saintsâ€™ Day, and All Soulsâ€™ Day). There are written references to the custom from as far back as 1511. Records from the 19th century show soul cakes as roundels containing flour, butter, sugar, currants, spices and eggs.

title: Want wines with attitude? Look to the Jura
excerpt: If youâ€™ve heard of savagnin (nope, not sauvignon), you may well be one of those in-the-know wine drinkers who have been ushered in the direction of the Jura , this grapeâ€™s iconic region, after being priced out of your favourite burgundy. And while there are some similarities bâ€¦

body:
If youâ€™ve heard of savagnin (nope, not sauvignon), you may well be one of those in-the-know wine drinkers who have been ushered in the direction of the Jura, this grapeâ€™s iconic region, after being priced out of your favourite burgundy. And while there are some similarities between the two regions, a focus on chardonnay and pinot noir being the most obvious, there are plenty of other varieties for discerning wine nerds, and savagnin is definitely one of them.

Itâ€™s a grape variety thatâ€™s been grown in France for 900 years, with high acidity and a late-ripening in the vineyard, and itâ€™s known for the complex, age-worthy styles of wine it can create. Itâ€™s also grown just over the border in Switzerland, where itâ€™s known as heida, as well as in Australia, where it was once mistaken for albariÃ±o. In the Jura, however, this high-acid grape produces nuanced still wines, and wines made in the vin jaune style, for which the wine is matured under yeast to give it a nutty, complex character akin to that of a biologically aged sherry such as fino.

The curious character of these wines makes them a sommelierâ€™s secret weapon, as Donald Edwards, consultant sommelier, tells me: â€œVin jaune scratches an itch thatâ€™s hard to sort any other way: oily, sharp, salty, a little bit wrong, but also ridiculously moreish. The Juraâ€™s chardonnays seem to rewrite exactly what that variety can be in terms of expression, but itâ€™s the savagnins that really epitomise the area, snarling at you, while at the same time being defiantly discordant in the most thrilling way. â€

Because of the regionâ€™s relatively small output (a quick glance at Decanter reveals 230 wineries and an average production of 11 million bottles, so a fraction of Franceâ€™s other regions), youâ€™re more likely to find savagnin, and other Jura wines, for that matter, in more boutique-y retailers. Theyâ€™re also likely to be a lot more expensive than, say, sauvignon, or any other such wine thatâ€™s produced everywhere and by everyone.

Imagine my surprise/shock/delight, then, when the Wine Society recently announced that itâ€™s bringing a cÃ´tes du Jura to its own-label range for Â£18.50. Yes, I know as well as you that this isnâ€™t a bargain in the literal sense, but itâ€™s not too bad a shout considering the 100% savagnin currently on the societyâ€™s website is Â£27, while a lot of other Jura frequently topples over the Â£30 mark. Hopefully, this might also open the doors for supermarkets and other big retailers to do the same, so my wallet can take less of a flogging every time I want to open my mouth to the nutty, savoury flavours of the Jura.

Four Jura wines to pique your interest

title: Smithsonian Secretary Responds to Trumpâ€™s Museum Crackdown
excerpt: Smithsonian Secretary Lonnie Bunch sent a letter to the Trump administration responding to a list of demands the White House presented last month as it attempts to assert control over the institution.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Smithsonian Secretary Lonnie Bunch sent a letter to the Trump administration responding to a list of demands the White House presented last month as it attempts to assert control over the institution.

Bunchâ€™s direct response to the White House comes more than three weeks after the administration attempted to compel the museum and research network to turn over curatorial materials, plans for the United Statesâ€™s 250th anniversary, visitor experience surveys, and other materials. Bunch met privately with President Trump last week.

Bunchâ€™s response, first reported by the New York Times, was not made public. A Smithsonian spokesperson reached by

Hyperallergicconfirmed the letter was sent but declined to share a copy or comment on its contents.

The Trump administration has sought to gut the Smithsonian of what it calls â€œdivisiveâ€ narratives and â€œrace-centered ideologyâ€ and install â€œunifying, historically accurate, and constructive descriptions.â€ In a tirade on his social media platform Truth Social, Trump has criticized the Smithsonian for focusing too much on â€œhow bad slavery was,â€ among other things. Last month, the White House notified the institution that it would conduct a review of the Smithsonian and make â€œcontent corrections.â€

Based on an email shared by Bunch with Smithsonian staff explaining what he told the president, the Times reported that the secretary defended the institutionâ€™s independence, but vowed to share certain information with the Trump administration. Bunch, in the description of his letter, said that the institution is already conducting its own review of content to ensure it is â€œnonpartisan and factual.â€ The Smithsonian would conduct this review, not the White House, Bunch reportedly said in the letter.

â€œOur own review of content to ensure our programming is nonpartisan and factual is ongoing, and it is consistent with our authority over our programming and content,â€ the letter said, according to the Times.

It is unclear, though, whether Bunch outright rejected Trumpâ€™s authority to issue â€œcontent correctionsâ€ on the independent institution. It is also unclear what information Bunch offered to share with the White House, and what say, if any, the institution would have in the Smithsonian-led process. If the Smithsonian doesnâ€™t comply with the White Houseâ€™s review, it could jeopardize its federal funding, which accounts for about 62% of its annual budget. The institution has yet to make a public statement addressing the White Houseâ€™s attempted audit of its targeting of specific items at the Smithsonian.

excerpt: This is exactly my kind of recipe. Itâ€™s easy, flavourful and, as a bonus, itâ€™s crispy, too. In fact, itâ€™s so simple, you could make the mixture with your eyes closed or, better still, give it to a six-year-old to do (they could also make it with their eyes closed). The key is â€¦
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
This is exactly my kind of recipe. Itâ€™s easy, flavourful and, as a bonus, itâ€™s crispy, too. In fact, itâ€™s so simple, you could make the mixture with your eyes closed or, better still, give it to a six-year-old to do (they could also make it with their eyes closed). The key is the black beans, because they crisp up perfectly, and the condiments, which supercharge the flavour. There is one small catch, though: the onions need caramelising until theyâ€™re jammy, and ready to top the patty. You donâ€™t have to do this, but Iâ€™m here to tell you that it is worthwhile (especially if thereâ€™s a six-year-old already making the burgers).

Crispy black bean burgers

If you like, prep the patties a day in advance and chill until needed.

Prep 10 min
Cook 30 min
Serves 4

Prep 10 min
Cook 30 min
Serves 4

Olive oil 2 large onions, peeled and thinly sliced

1 tsp salt
400g tin black beans, not drained

400g tin black beans

80g dried breadcrumbs
1 tsp dried garlic granules
1 tsp dried onion granules
1 tbsp chipotle paste
2 tsp dijon mustard
1 tbsp tomato ketchup

1 tsp dried garlic granules

1 tsp dried onion granules

1 tbsp chipotle paste

2 tsp dijon mustard

1 tbsp tomato ketchup

To serve4 burger buns Vegan mayonnaise Iceberg lettuce Finely sliced tomato

Put three tablespoons of olive oil in a medium frying pan set over a medium heat and, once itâ€™s hot, add the onion and a half-teaspoon of salt, and cook, stirring often, for 20 minutes, until quite reduced and frazzled. Take off the heat.

Meanwhile, spoon a couple of tablespoons of the liquid (aquafaba) from the tin of beans into a small bowl or mug and set aside. Drain and rinse the beans, tip into a large bowl and roughly mash; leave a few whole or in big chunks. Stir in the breadcrumbs, garlic granules, onion granules, chipotle paste, mustard, ketchup and a half-teaspoon of salt, then use your hands to mix until well combined; if need be, add some or all of the reserved aquafaba.

Divide the bean mix evenly into four, roll each piece into a ball, then put them one by one between two sheets of baking paper and press out to roughly 10cm- to 12cm-wide patties (I tend to make mine a wee bit bigger than the burger buns).

To cook the patties, put two tablespoons of olive oil in a medium frying pan, then fry two of the burgers for about six minutes in total, turning them once halfway, or when the base is crisp and golden. Remove and set aside, add another two tablespoons of oil, then repeat with the other two patties.

To serve, split and toast the buns, spread a generous dollop of mayo over the cut side of the bases and top with a leaf or two of iceberg lettuce. Add a bean patty and a couple of thin slices of tomato, and finish with a quarter of the caramelised onions. On with the lids and eat immediately.

excerpt: This summer classic is the happy proof that not all things labelled as salad have to feel like penance for helping yourself to all the fried chicken or barbecued halloumi. Far fresher and zingier than gloopy, ready-made versions, this is the perfect recipe to make the most of â€¦
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
This summer classic is the happy proof that not all things labelled as salad have to feel like penance for helping yourself to all the fried chicken or barbecued halloumi. Far fresher and zingier than gloopy, ready-made versions, this is the perfect recipe to make the most of those dense, fudgy early potatoes, and easy to customise according to taste and circumstance.

Prep 15 min
Cook 15-20 min
Serves 4

600g waxy potatoes Salt Â½ tsp dijon mustard 1 tbsp red-wine vinegar 2 tbsp neutral oil, such as sunflower

1 tbsp extra-virgin olive oil
115g good mayonnaise, ordinary or plant-based (see step 6 for a homemade option)

115g good mayonnaise

3 spring onions
2 tbsp capers and/or chopped gherkins
2 anchovies(optional)

2 tbsp capers and/or chopped gherkins

2 anchovies

1 small bunch chives
1 handful

1 handful

fresh parsley, leaves and soft stems


1 handful fresh mint leaves

1 handful fresh mint leaves

1 tbsp wholegrain mustard

1 Go for new, waxy potatoes â€¦

Potato salad demands a waxy variety, and preferably ones that are new enough that their skins are still flaky and thin, rather than spuds that have been in cold storage for months. Jersey royals are my favourite, but other good (and widely available) options include celandine, ratte, arran, pink fir apple and vivaldi, though farm shops may have even better options on offer.

2 â€¦ and try to buy small ones

Choose potatoes that are fairly even in size, and preferably small enough easily to boil whole; you may need to cut any larger ones in half to ensure they all cook through in roughly the same time, but try to minimise this, because potatoes cooked whole in their skins will have a better texture.

3 Prep the spuds

Give the potatoes a good wash; true new potatoes should still have some dirt clinging to their frail skins, but donâ€™t bother to peel them any more than necessary, because those skins hold much of the flavour, and also protect the potato flesh from the hot water. Put the spuds in a pan just large enough to hold them all comfortably.

4 Cook the spuds

Add enough cold water just to cover, then salt very generously (donâ€™t worry, because most of it will go down the drain after cooking). Cover and bring to a boil, then uncover, turn down the heat and simmer until just cooked through (test the largest potato with a fork or skewer to check). This method takes longer than dropping them in boiling water, but it means that the outsides wonâ€™t overcook.

5 Start the dressing

Meanwhile, in a large bowl, whisk the mustard (any variety will do here, but I like the tanginess of dijon), vinegar (cider or white-wine would work, as would lemon juice) and a pinch of salt until smooth, then gradually whisk in the oils â€“ if you prefer your dressing to have a lighter or stronger flavour, feel free to use neutral or olive oil alone, respectively.

6 For a homemade mayo

Drain the potatoes, put them back in the hot pan to steam dry, then cut in half or quarters.

Toss with the vinaigrette and leave to cool.

For a quick mayonnaise, in a container thatâ€™s just wider than the head of your stick blender, whizz an egg â€“ or, for a plant-based alternative, four tablespoons of aquafaba and 10 chickpeas â€“ with a tablespoon of mustard and a teaspoon of vinegar or lemon juice.

7 Finish the mayo

Pour 225ml neutral oil and 25ml extra-virgin olive oil on top of the egg or chickpea mixture, then put the stick blender on the base of the container and whizz at high speed until you see white clouds billow up from underneath. At this point, lift the still whizzing blender head very slowly, and mix until all the oil is combined. Season to taste.

title: Meera Sodhaâ€™s vegan recipe for squash and fennel agrodolce | The new vegan
excerpt: Being in the business of recipe writing means I am always seeking the new, always moving on and rarely resting on a single dish. Until summer starts knocking, that is. The sun makes me want to slow down, and I find myself wanting a variation of vegetables agrodolce on repeat. â€¦
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Being in the business of recipe writing means I am always seeking the new, always moving on and rarely resting on a single dish. Until summer starts knocking, that is. The sun makes me want to slow down, and I find myself wanting a variation of vegetables agrodolce on repeat. Agrodolce is Italian for sour (agro) and sweet (dolce), which in my kitchen translates to a pile of meltingly soft vegetables, all slick with olive oil, sweet with onions, and cut with vinegar and capers. Often, this takes the form of my husband Hughâ€™s oven-baked caponata, but I also love the comfort of squash and the liquorice sweetness of the cooked fennel here.

Squash and fennel agrodolce

Prep 15 minCook

40 min

Serves

4

1 squash (1.1kg), halved, deseeded and cut into 1Â½cm dice8 tbsp extra-virgin olive oil, plus extra to finishFine sea salt 2 tbsp capers in brine, drained

2 tbsp pine nuts
2 tbsp raisins
1 fennel bulb(300g), trimmed, halved and cut into Â½cm-thick slices

2 tbsp raisins

1 fennel bulb

1 red onion, peeled and finely diced

2 large tomatoes(300g), finely diced

2 tbsp balsamic vinegar
30g mint, leaves picked, to get 15g

30g mint

Greek flatbreads, to serve

Heat the oven to 240C (220C fan)/475F/gas 9, and line two medium baking trays (or one large tray) with greaseproof paper.

Put the diced squash in a bowl, pour over three tablespoons of the oil, add a half-teaspoon of salt and toss to coat. Tip out evenly on the lined trays and roast for 25-30 minutes, until cooked through and nicely browned.

Meanwhile, put two tablespoons of oil in a large frying pan on a medium heat and, once hot, add the drained capers and cook for five minutes, until they start to crisp up. Add the pine nuts and raisins, cook for a further two minutes, until the raisins puff up and the pine nuts brown, then tip into a bowl.

Put the remaining three tablespoons of oil in the same pan, set it over a medium heat, then add the fennel, onion and three-quarters of a teaspoon of salt, and cook, stirring occasionally, for 20 minutes, until soft. Add the tomatoes and balsamic vinegar, and cook for another eight minutes, until the mixture turns jammy. Fold in the roast squash and reheat, if need be, then stir through the mint.

Top with the pine nut mixture and serve with grilled flatbreads.

I was thinking of billing this as a caesar salad with an extreme makeover. One night, I started making a caesar salad, then wondered what would happen if I made a coriander-pesto mayonnaise and mugged off the anchovies in favour of chorizo. Then I thought about turning it into a full meal, at which point it stopped being anything like a caesar salad. If youâ€™d prefer a vegetarian version, choose a vegetarian parmesan and omit the chorizo in favour of a heaped teaspoon of smoked paprika and a scant teaspoon of sea salt flakes.

Put a tablespoon of oil in a large, heavy-based saucepan on a high heat. I canâ€™t make gazpacho without thinking of Pedro AlmodÃ³varâ€™s Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown. If you havenâ€™t seen it, I highly recommend that you do, and not just for the iconic spiked gazpacho scene. This version is also spiked, but more tamely with watermelon, which lends a wonderful sweetness. You can go as simple or as extra as you like with the toppings: I, of course, like to go extra with cherry tomatoes of varying colours, ice cubes, micro basil, finely cubed cucumber and a swirl of my best extra-virgin olive oil to finish.

ideally

title: Hearts Touched With Fire: Horror and Hope in a Time of Genocide
excerpt: Move him into the sunâ€“
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Move him into the sunâ€“


Gently its touch awoke him once,
At home, whispering of fields unseen.
Always it woke him, even in France,
Until this morning and this snow.
If anything might rouse him now
The kind old sun will know.
Think how it wakes the seedsâ€”
Woke once the clays of a cold star.
Are limbs, so dear-achieved, are sides
Full-nerved, still warm, too hard to stir?
Was it for this the clay grew tall?
â€”O what made fatuous sunbeams toil
To break earthâ€™s sleep at all?

â€“

Wilfred Owen, â€œFutility,â€ May 1918*

It has never been worse than this. The last time I wrote of Palestine, in February 2024, the invasion of Rafahâ€”Joe Bidenâ€™s supposed red lineâ€”had just begun. Since then, the IDF has obliterated the ancient city, along with most of the rest of Gaza. Tens of thousands of Palestinians have been confirmed killedâ€”by Israeli bombs, bullets, and starvationâ€”though the true number is, in all likelihood, far higher. The long-threatened famine is here. Hundreds have already died of starvation. More than a thousand people have been gunned down while queuing for food at Gaza Humanitarian Foundation â€œaidâ€ sites. The West Bank, without even the pretext of a Hamas presence, is under a state of dual siege. The IDF executes a relentless campaign of urban destruction, kidnapping, and murder, while a juiced-up army of settlers spreads terror among the Palestinian population, vandalizing, looting, burning, and lynching, safe in the knowledge that the police, army and courts are on their side.

In the last two decades the conviction rate for incidents of settler violence was a paltry 3%, according to Israeli human rights NGO Yesh Din. Since far right settler and Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich took personal command of West Bank governance, the situation has become yet worse. Two years of relentless violence have stripped the artifice from the Israeli political system. Seemingly every day brings another pronouncement, each one gobsmacking in its genocidal intent, from a politician quoting Hitler as a model for what should be done, to Smotrichâ€™s repeated demands for ethnic cleansing and settlement of Gaza. Now, in preparation for a ground invasion, Israel rains yet more American bombs on Gaza Cityâ€”another round of mindless, brutal violence against a population that has endured it every day for almost two years.Â 

Horror of this scale has the effect of deadening words, making stories of the most unimaginable violence land with a dull thud. We are used to it, even as new levels of depravity are uncovered on a weekly basis. I have seen every one of the most obscene images of violence of my life in the last two years. As teenagers we would stumble upon images like this very occasionally. Moments of surreal and genuine violence, usually culled from video nasties like Faces of Death, old VHS transfers of 35mm film further pixelated into short animated GIFs. Now, new high-fidelity snuff films are created daily, and we see them in our Instagram feeds next to pictures of holidays and ads for Volvos. Ash and fire and endless grey dusty death. Not that itâ€™s anywhere near the most important thing to think about, but this daily bombardment of images of death is having a devastating psychological effect on everyone who experiences it.

As a lifelong agnostic, I find more kinship among people of faith who oppose this war than fellow non-believers who stay silent.

All of this has been said before, and yet itâ€™s worth saying again. The deliberate policy of the Israeli government is to flood the world with so many crimes that it becomes impossible to hold on to any one image or report for any length of time. As Nemick says in the first series of Andor, itâ€™s easier to hide behind forty atrocities than one single incident. (A couple of years ago, I might have been embarrassed to quote a Star Wars character; nowadays I find I donâ€™t much care where I get my encouragement from. Why be embarrassed about anything else, when the whole world is party to an obscenity that shames us all?)

title: I Canâ€™t Let Go of a Ten-Year-Old Literary Grudge: Am I the Asshole?
excerpt: Howdy, campers! Welcome back to the latest installment of everyoneâ€™s favorite petty gossip rag, Am I the Literary Asshole? , a column that does NOT currently require a payment plan! Iâ€™m your host, Kristen Arnett, and Iâ€™m excited to say that weâ€™ve officially entered into â€œmeteoâ€¦
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Kristen Arnett Answers Your Awkward Questions About Bad Bookish Behavior

Howdy, campers! Welcome back to the latest installment of everyoneâ€™s favorite petty gossip rag, Am I the Literary Asshole?, a column that does NOT currently require a payment plan! Iâ€™m your host, Kristen Arnett, and Iâ€™m excited to say that weâ€™ve officially entered into â€œmeteorological fall,â€ which I think means that if I see my shadow, I get five more seasonal craft beers. Incredible!

Since itâ€™s technically autumn (I say this as I check the temperature outside in Florida and see that itâ€™s currently clocking in at 89 degrees), why donâ€™t we enjoy one of those aforementioned seasonal brews while we check out todayâ€™s quandaries? Theyâ€™ve got a quaint spiced flavor and a picture of a cartoon pumpkin on the label! CUTE!

Here we go, locked and loaded:

1) Hi Dad, long time reader, 2nd time questioner. Iâ€™m a sometimes poet who has had a little bit of work published but, of course, would like some more. I need to know if Iâ€™m the literary arsehole, if I donâ€™t really â€œpolishâ€ my work? Donâ€™t get me wrong, I reread and change or correct as I see appropriate, but I donâ€™t feel a poemâ€”or any writing reallyâ€”needs to be â€œhigh sheen.â€ In fact, all the work Iâ€™ve had published has been off the cuff and the stuff Iâ€™ve worked onâ€”in one case, for almost two years, has been rejected as â€œneeds more work.â€ Iâ€™ve also had my work professionally assessed and it seems to reach the proper standard, so Iâ€™m no longer sure. Am I an arsehole, or just lazy? Or neither, just not very good (I donâ€™t expect you to answer thatâ€”how could you?)

First of all, love the idea that people are coming back for a second round of answers! I must be doing something right!

Now, when it comes to your question, Iâ€™m going to unpack things here a little before we dig into the meat of things. â€œPolishâ€ is the word youâ€™ve used here, but I think itâ€™s possible that you ARE, in fact, doing the very thing that you said you were not doing. If you admit that you â€œreread and change and correctâ€ your work when youâ€™re in your document and tooling around, then I would argue that you ARE polishing it. â€œHigh sheenâ€ is a very interesting word choice here, too. Itâ€™s possible that by â€œpolishingâ€ or â€œhigh sheenâ€ you mean you donâ€™t do several rounds of intense drafts (i.e. â€œworking_title_draft_2782178_FINAL_ real _FINAL FINAL_forrealthistime_FINAL.docx]. Thatâ€™s not unusual, though!

Many writersâ€”myself includedâ€”stick inside one original document and fiddle around with that work until it sticks. I like things to feel off the cuff so that I can surprise myself. Thatâ€™s when I generally get work that I like best from myself. Then I fine tune it (like how you mentioned in your letter). I clean up the language, look at the sentences, essentially â€œpolishâ€ it up. But for the most part, the work stays the same.

If you ask anyone, theyâ€™re going to tell you some variation of a working strategy. Some people have multiple drafts, others donâ€™t. Some people need lots of eyes on work, while other people prefer to keep it hidden until itâ€™s completely done. In all honesty, itâ€™s totally possible to sit for years in a draft and just keep moving the same words around into infinity. The reality is that clean up in never â€œdone.â€ We reach a point where we say that the story or essay or poem is complete because itâ€™s gotten the closest to the ideal we were trying to create. â€œPolishâ€ (or whatever you want to call it) is simply the amount YOU need to do as the writer to consider the draft done.

Itâ€™s possible that Iâ€™m misunderstanding what youâ€™re writing to me about, but from what I see here, I donâ€™t think youâ€™re being a lazy writer. If youâ€™re making things that you think stand firmly on their own two feet, then youâ€™re doing the work that you should be doing. And thatâ€™s not asshole behavior!

title: Big Sister Writer, Little Brother Editor: Can They Work Together?
excerpt: While planning this interview, my sister and I were on the phone (as we are most days) and I said I would write up the introduction and she said I should send it to her for edits and then she said SHE would write it up and send it to ME for edits, and things generally devolvedâ€¦
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
While planning this interview, my sister and I were on the phone (as we are most days) and I said I would write up the introduction and she said I should send it to her for edits and then she said SHE would write it up and send it to ME for edits, and things generally devolved from there about who wrote â€œturgid proseâ€ (me) and who was bossy and annoying (her).

This banter was much in evidence as her debut novel, Hot Desk, came into being. I delivered the spark of an idea for the book (literally one line), but knew I didnâ€™t have the time or the talent to write it. My sister had both.

Since half the book takes place in a contemporary publishing office, where I have spent over 30 years, I could provide details about zoom meetings gone awry and the indignity of phone pods. But for the second timeline, New York City in the early 1980s, she delved into her own experience working as an intern at The Paris Review to bring those sections vividly alive, and eventually my role was mostly relegated to harassing her via a talking panda emoji to HURRY UP AND FINISH.

Connecting over Hot Desk brought us back to our childhoods, our love of books, and the bond we have always shared. Six years older, she did everything cooler first. And I happily followed in her footsteps. She would probably say shadow. We both majored in English and worked at the college literary magazine. We both spent a year studying literature at the University of Edinburgh. We both interned at The Paris Review. But she was always a writer, and I was just a voracious reader, and then an editor.

What follows is a transcript of our conversation about what itâ€™s like to be siblings interested in the same things, how reading prodigiously and maybe a bit recklessly as children shaped us, how our paths led us first to different places and then to Hot Desk. Though we are both controlling, opinionated, and foul mouthed, most profanity has been cut.

*
Colin Dickerman: My earliest memory of perhaps having read too much, too early, was writingâ€¯something in a (well-deserved) burn book aimed at a very obnoxious 4th grade classmate. My entry unfortunatelyâ€¯quoted a particularly vicious line from a Stephen King novel. When the teacher confiscated it, she was â€œdisturbedâ€ I knew such a â€œsophisticatedâ€â€¯ insult. Yes, I remember what it was (shame cuts deep), and, no, I wonâ€™t tell you.â€¯Did you ever have a similar moment of reading beyond your years in a way that got you in trouble or somehow had a negative impact in the real world?

Laura Dickerman: God, we read everything all the time! I remember going to the Shelburne Library once a week and checking out an enormous armful of books then sitting on the couch and reading straight through. Anna Karenina and Flowers in the Attic in the same haul. I mean, how were kids allowed to read Flowers in the Attic? I never used my sophisticated knowledge for evil as you did, but I do recall the humiliation of confidently mispronouncing words I had only ever read: melon-cholly for melancholy and chick for chic and col-lone-el for colonel, etc. I am lucky that I drowned out the horror of Flowers in the Attic with many, many bodice-rippers.

CD: I think one of the greatest benefits of having read so much as a kid, particularly â€œadultâ€ books, is that I never had to ask our parents one question about sex. â€¯That, and being super popular when I brought Judy Blumeâ€™sâ€¯Wifeyâ€¯to school, with all relevant passages dog-eared. What benefits did you see?

title: The Annotated Nightstand: What Kevin Young Is Reading Now, and Next
excerpt: In his new collection Night Watch; poems , poet Kevin Young attends to as seemingly disparate topics: the moon, Danteâ€™s Divine Comedy , birds, conjoined twin singers made into a freak show act, graves, flowers. This is made manifest through four sections (two comprising the maâ€¦
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Featuring Nicholas Boggs, Mavis Gallant, Jack Kerouac and More

In his new collection Night Watch; poems, poet Kevin Young attends to as seemingly disparate topics: the moon, Danteâ€™s Divine Comedy, birds, conjoined twin singers made into a freak show act, graves, flowers. This is made manifest through four sections (two comprising the majority of the book). By this description Night Watch appears to be a book concerning the wonders of the quotidian or the darkness of humanityâ€”as in the section on Millie and Christine McCoy, enslaved conjoined twins who sang in shows in the United States. After a life of forced medical scrutiny and freak show displays, their liberation brings them the opportunity to perform around Europe and their nation that had previously kept them enslaved.

As with his other writing on historical figures (I think especially of my fan favorite, Ardency), Young plumbs some of the most shameful parts of our nationâ€™s history and societyâ€™s violences and holds them up to the light. â€œMillie-Christine,â€ as they were singular, are allowed voice, interiority, and nuance in these poems. â€œIt is our mind / doctors without schooling fail / to mention,â€ they say.

Yet, above all, Night Watch is a book defined by grief and the existential trembling before the precipice of mortality and how we bear witness to loss. It is dedicated to three loved ones Young lost a year apart. â€œWe were born / with all our grief already in us,â€ he writes, â€œlike teeth.â€ Youngâ€™s interrogation of death and what is after is made most explicit in the series of poems in conversation with the Inferno (which began as a dialog of poems with Robin Coste Lewis responding to Robert Rauschenbergâ€™s â€œDante drawingsâ€). Through these pages we descend with Young into the circles of hell, walk with the devil, see how the living contend with the dead (or donâ€™t). The moon looks down like a terrible eye at what humans have wrought, how we grope around for meaning. â€œWhen I go // donâ€™t dare sing Amazing Â / Grace,â€ Young writes, â€œthat tune / some slaveholder wrote // while at sea, the National / Anthem of suffering.â€ In its starred review, Publishers Weekly writes, â€œThis elegant volume deepens the body of work by a significant American poet.â€

Young tells us: â€œMost but not all of my to-be-read pile is made up of new and older books related to the next nonfiction history Iâ€™m working on, which starts in expatriate Paris between the World Wars; it ends in postwar Paris and stateside in Harlem. Writers like Baldwin, Beckett, and Hughes figure prominentlyâ€”and are just great to read and read about. Iâ€™m looking forward to diving further into the others, including the latest translation of Rumi.â€

*

Rumi (tr. Haleh Liza Gafori),

Water

Lit Hubâ€™s own Christopher Spaide recommended this new translation a few months ago, writing, â€œWater, for Gaforiâ€™s Rumi, is a versatile, metamorphosing substance, here a fountain, there a torrent, alternately refreshing and engulfing us, extinguishing our passions and cleaning us up: â€˜You canâ€™t put out fire, dear boy, / with another fire. // You canâ€™t wash my heartâ€™s open wound / with anotherâ€™s blood.â€™ â€¦ Like the most engaging playlists, Gaforiâ€™s selection boasts idiosyncratic connections and ear-catching tempo changes, from sequences and litanies to unimprovably terse epigrams.â€

Samuel Beckett,

Watt

â€œIn the summer of 1942, Samuel Beckett and his partner Suzanne Dechevaux-Dumesnil fled their apartment in the German-occupied city of Paris,â€ writes Jon Michaud at the New Yorker. â€œBeckett and Dechevaux-Dumesnil rented quarters in a house on the edge of town and proceeded to wait out the war. It was a long and difficult wait. Beckett, prone to anxiety, suffered a mental breakdownâ€¦ He also labored on a novel,

Watt,â€™ which heâ€™d begun the previous year, in Paris, and which, he said, provided him â€˜a means of staying sane.â€™â€

Paris Notebooks

Escape Pod 1009: The Combat Pilotâ€™s Dictionary

The Combat Pilotâ€™s Dictionary

Boot

Rookie pilot. See also â€“ nugget.

You called us â€˜bootsâ€™ when we turned up to the flight deck that first morning I laid eyes on you.

The halogen lighting shone down onto the makeshift parade ground with a harsh insistence matched only by your loud drill calls.

You looked the part. Milspec features matched with an impeccably pressed grey uniform. Hair shorn close to the scalp to fit the Z94-OptiGuard Quiklok Aerospace Aviation Helmet that you wore in combat. Broad shoulders and piercing eyes. Tall and built like a true Martian. Rust in your blood.

Â 

Chaff

Radar countermeasures. Thin dipoles of aluminium ejected into space to fool radar-guided ordinance.

You tried to dodge the question after that first sortie.

I caught you coming out of the head with your towel around your waist and hair damp from the twenty second spray of water that passed for a â€˜showerâ€™ on the carrier Cardinal Spear.

â€œBoss, do you want to grab a drink?â€

You mumbled something about getting too comfortable around superiors and strode off, but even I couldnâ€™t miss the way your cheeks lit up redder than a hostile on radar.

Successful disengage.

DNI

Direct Neural Interface. Cutting-edge pilot-machine control technology.

It took us a while to get used to having that chip in our heads.

The techs kept the tactile controls in the cockpit thoughâ€”something about our evolutionary need to use our hands to manipulate things. The result was the same: you pulled up on the stick and your Remora would jet up along a Z-axis climb, only the DNI made it happen so much faster.

It was disconcerting at first. Lots of training focused on keeping our minds in gear during air combat manoeuvres. Panic, think the wrong thing, and youâ€™d end up a red smear against the cockpit.

You were always a natural, though. Thatâ€™s why you were an instructor, I guess.

The first time I watched you gracefully soar out of the hangar, then dive down into the target drones with your barrels blazing, I knew why they called you Peregrine.

The first time I watched you step back out of the cockpit, sweat soaking your black hair and red flushing your cheeks, I knew you were special.

Dance, The

Air combat manoeuvres. See alsoâ€” furball.

You took your whisky with a splash of glacial meltwater, settled into your favourite chair in the ready room, and told me about the dance.

Your eyes lit up when you told me about the way you felt behind the sticks. It wasnâ€™t a machine to you. It was so much more.

â€œWings! Thatâ€™s what it feels like!â€ You slammed your fist on the table to emphasise your point. â€œYou know when youâ€™re a kid, and you get those dreams about flying? Thatâ€™s what itâ€™s like, except sometimes I feel like this is the dream, yâ€™know? Like out there, out in the dance, thatâ€™s real. Thatâ€™s all that matters.â€

â€œWhat about family? Anyone back home?â€

â€œNah, came out here on rotation and never left. Someone has to teach you nuggets how to not get killed,â€ you said.

â€œMy familyâ€™s all gone. Bombing. Thatâ€™s why I signed up.â€

You were silent for a moment.

You look younger when youâ€™re out of your flight suit. The squadron jacket suits you.

I put my hand on yours and smile.

â€œIâ€™m glad youâ€™re out here with me, boss.â€

Â 

E-WAR

Electronic warfare. Includes electronic countermeasures (jammers), remote power dampening, weapon disruption modules.

The reactor spike put the Cardinal Spear onto emergency power for three days while we drifted in the orbit of Io.

You told me this was the second time it had happened to a carrier you were serving on. Microwave power disruption from a cloaked corvette. Everything was down, from maglev launch tubes to atmospheric control, so we carried portable batteries with us and huddled together for warmth under big, insulated blankets.

I wasnâ€™t complaining.

â€œDonâ€™t worry about it,â€ you told me as we lay together in your quarters. â€œIf they wanted us dead, weâ€™d be dead by now.â€

â€œComforting.â€
